results.description:
Single? New in town? Just looking to get out and meet new people?

Join us for our multi-group member happy hour! ATWYS along with New York Social Network organizes a monthly Saturday night get together for all of our new and existing members.

If you are new to our Meteup group or a long time member, this is a fun night to meet others and find out what what we have planned in the coming months. Event Host, New York Social Network  founder Dave Cervini will be on hand with our staff to welcome all New Members and introduce you to our long time members.  You will enjoy drink specials,  complimentary hot and cold appetizers and lot's of room to socialize network and connect.

The World Bar is a nice lounge with lot's of room to sit or wander around while meeting others.

Other Meet Up and Social Networking groups/organizations often invite their members so you also get to network with people from similiar groups.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$5 in advance only - $10 at door if available

Prepay here: http://atwys2013member.eventbrite.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


The night will include:

-complimentary hot and cold appetizers until 9pm

-Drink specials until 9pm

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending tend to come on their own.

What to expect: 60-80 people fairly even split of men and women ages 20's -40's, singles and some couples. Most are there to network and connect. 

What to wear: trendy, neat, business casual

How do I get there? take any of the green line trains to 42nd Grand Central or 51st street. Then a short walk towards the East River

How long does it go?  We usually start breaking up around 12:30-1am.

group.name: And That's Why You're Single Events - NYC - Singles 25-55

results.description:
Please note:  This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's New York Social Network and 7 of their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP's listed on this Meet Up reflect only a portion of those attending.  If you have any questions about this event .  Please contact the event host Dave Cervini directly at [masked]


The New York Social Network (NYSN) has been planning events in and around the city since 2004!  There is something to choose from almost every night and several options each weekend!  It can be hard to figure out which ones may be best for you, especially if you have never been out before.

If you are new to the group or a long time member, this is a fun night to meet others and find out what what we have planned in the coming months. NYSN founder Dave Cervini will be on hand with our staff to welcome all New Members and introduce you to our long time members.  You will enjoy drink specials,  complimentary hot and cold appetizers and lot's of room to socialize network and connect.

The World Bar is a nice lounge with lot's of room to sit or wander around while meeting others.

Other Meet Up and Social Networking groups/organizations often invite their members so you also get to network with people from similar groups.

The night will include:

-complimentary hot and cold appetizers until 9pm

-Drink specials until 9pm

-Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes, 95% of those attending tend to come on their own.

What to expect: 60-80 people fairly even split of men and women ages 20's -40's, singles and some couples. Most are there to network and connect.

Why does the event organizer have +40 for his RSVP's? That is because there are 8 Meetup.com groups and www.newyorksocialnetwork.com promoting this event.  There will be many more people than what you see below attending.

What to wear: trendy, neat, business casual

How do I get there? take any of the green line trains to 42nd Grand Central or 51st street. Then a short walk towards the East River

How long does it go?  We usually start breaking up around 12:30-1am.

General Admission is $5.00.  Please bring exact change to the door.

This event is being sponsored by The New York Social Network which is a collaboration of several different Meet Up Groups (

www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

).  The number of RSVP's below reflect only a portion of those attending.  Please only sign up for this event if you are serious about attending.  We have a 3 flakes and you are out rule!  If you have questions regarding this or other events, please contact the event host Dave Cervini at[masked] or e-mail [masked].

results.description:
Unique to SHUFFLE Concert performances is the manner in which the program is selected. The audience is invited to actively participate in the selection of works to be performed by choosing from a menu of over 30 works derived from 15 different styles, with works ranging from solos and duos, to trios, quartets, quintets and sextets. Genres vary from classical, baroque, and romantic, to Jazz, pop and Broadway. The result is a highly engaged audience and a high energy performance.

SHUFFLE’s members are exceptionally accomplished chamber musicians; they are graduates of such schools as Juilliard, New England Conservatory, Oberlin, Manhattan School of Music and Bard College and have all individually won numerous prizes and have performed extensively as soloists and collaborative musicians throughout the world.

FREE tickets available here: ChamberMusicNY presents SHUFFLE

SAMPLE menu:
results.name: ChamberMusicNY presents SHUFFLE Concert at Merkin Concert Hall

group.name: The New York Chamber Music Meetup

results.description:
Ladies and Gentlemen,

You are cordially invited to come out and shake ya groove thang with us once again at Toda La Noche @Stepping Out Studios. This is one of the top salsa party's going in NYC to date.

 Hosted and Organized by Nicholas Messina of Bongo Loco NYC Salsa at Stepping Out Studios, with co-promoter Crystal Rodriguez. Come be a part of our very special, ONCE a month Party. 

In addition to our infamous duo DJ Rudy "the power of love" Acosta and DJ Mustachio aka Jonathan Jorge! There will be great dancers, amazing people, great music, instruments, cold drinks, good vibes and warm smiles from Britnee and Magen Rodriguez, Yoaldry Espinosa De Messina and Jacob Lugo. Come out and celebrate with the Bongo Loco Crew.

Only $10 between 8-10pm and $12 from 10pm on.

See you on the dance floor,

Bongo Loco Productions.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the Building
results.name: Bongo Loco's Today La Noche

results.description:
https://youtu.be/RvwLIT_odG4

Let's go see great dance in New York City!!! 


The Fall for Dance Festival is a great festival presenting the best dance companies around the world for little or no cost. 

I'm proposing we go on Saturday, October 3rd for the 8PM show.

The festival runs for twelve days!! So if you can go to more shows, don't miss the chance. It's a great opportunity to celebrate and enjoy dance.

We're working out the ticket buying, so please let us know if you want to go:

1. Do you want to us to help coordinate transportation to and from NYC, or will you get there on your own?

2. Do you want us to help coordinate dinner gatherings in NYC?

3. Do you want to participate in our effort to buy tickets, or will you buy your own ticket on Sunday, September 13th at 11am (buy September 13th at noon, they could be sold out). They do offer online ticket buying. 

Here are some more details...

The Festival runs from Sep 30 - Oct 11, 2015

All tickets $15

Experience the very best the dance world has to offer at New York City Center’s 12th annual Fall for DanceFestival, where you’ll see world-renowned companies performing alongside daring new artists. The Festival’s five programs will feature two commissioned works and companies from all over the country, as well as from Brazil, India, Israel, and beyond. Come to the theater early and take part in free dance lessons and talks by choreographers, artists, and dance critics. Click here for the full lineup of the festival!

Below are details for the program I picked on Saturday October 3rd:

PROGRAM FOR SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3 at 8pm


LA COMPAGNIE HERVÉ KOUBI, What the Day Owes to the Night (US Premiere), Hervé Koubi 

STEVEN MCRAE, Czardas (US Premiere), Steven McRae 

PROJECT FFD: PAM TANOWITZ, New Work (NY Premiere, FFD Co-Commission), Pam Tanowitz 

ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER, Four Corners, Ronald K. Brown

  LA COMPAGNIE HERVÉ KOUBI
results.name: Dance Field Trip to New York City: Fall For Dance Festival!

results.description:
ALL AGES
$10 @ The Door = 4 hours of jamming & practice time! 

The Open Jams at Funkadelic Studios are great for musicians who are interested in networking with other like-minded artists, from beginners to professionals in all genres. Attending our open jams allows you to collaborate with musicians, and it's a great way to find potential band members, or to test out and get feedback on new songs that you’re working on!

Since first opening up in 1993, we have become a resource for artists of varying styles and personalities. The atmosphere at Funk, is influenced by our friendly staff and the cool vibe of our city.

Our Open Jams are held every Saturday and its only $10 to attend which gets you four hours of jamming and practice time! So come get something started, network, create and collaborate!
results.how_to_find_us: 5th Floor, on W40th between 7th & 8th ave.

venue.name: NORTH STREET TAVERN @ The Maple Moor Golf Club

results.description:
COME JOIN US AS WE "PARTY TIL WE FALL" FOR A NIGHT FILLED WITH COCKTAILS, DINING, DANCING, AND ADVENTURE AT OUR SOIREE UNDER THE STARS AT THE NORTH STREET TAVERN!

HAVE A FUN AND EXCITING EVENING WHILE MEETING SINGLES FROM ALL OVER CT & NY IN A WARM, COMFORTABLE SETTING BY THE GREEN.

11 0THER SINGLE GROUPS WILL BE JOINING US!

THE OUTSIDE DECK IS STILL OPEN SO PREPARE FOR SOME FUN AND GOOD TIMES UNDER THE STARS

THIS IS A MULTI-MEETUP GROUP EVENT. OVER 100 SINGLES WILL BE ATTENDING. THE RSVP LIST ON THIS PAGE ONLY SHOWS THE ACTUAL ATTENDEES THAT  HAVE R.S.V.P.'d.

IF YOU HAVEN'T R.S.V.P.'d YET, PLEASE DO SO NOW TO KEEP AN ACCURATE COUNT!

BRING A FRIEND

Carpool if you can and bring someone you know, a friend, a neighbor, a fellow co-worker or grab an ex-relationship (one without a restraining order) and get down to one of the best Singles Mixer around!

PLEASE DRESS TO IMPRESS OR CASUALLY NEAT!

Just 35 min. from Brewster, 25 min. from Norwalk, 35 min. from Peekskill, and 40 min. form NYC.

THE MUSIC

DJ Radio Personality, Matt Zako will be <a>spinning top</a> 40 and Retro tunes and taking your requests starting around 9 PM in the main dining room. We'll have all your favorite dance tunes playing so there's something for everyone's musical taste!

PARKING

We have all the convenient Parking you'll need right in front of the restaurant. After parking enter through the side door.

COVER CHARGE

There will be a $5 cover at the door to enter regardless of whether you're dining or just at the bar.

Please pay as you arrive and <a>exact change</a> will be appreciated. Thank You!

NORTH STREET TAVERN

Welcome to the newly renovated North Street Tavern, right off of exit 25 on the Hutchinson River Parkway.

The North Street Tavern situated on the Maple Moor Golf Course has great food, a large bar, a outdoor patio and dining room, all overlooking the golf course.

The North Street Tavern serves up Westchester Counties finest brick oven pizza and exciting dishes in a unique ambiance. The authentic <a>menu</a> and friendly atmosphere creates a truly enjoyable dining experience for all.

DIRECTIONS

~From CONNECTICUT~

Get on 95 S. to 287 W. (Exit 21) then take the Hutchinson River Parkway S. (Exit 9S), get off at Exit 25 and take a right at the bottom of the ramp, the Golf Course will be on your right.

You can also get on the Merit Parkway which turns into the Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off exit 25.

From Danbury, take 684 S. to Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off at Exit 25, at the end of the ramp take a right and the Golf Course will be on the right.

Just 30 min. from Norwalk, 40 min. Danbury, and 20 min. from Stamford.

~From NEW YORK~

From Points North, take 684 S. to Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off at Exit 25, at the end of the ramp take a right and the Golf Course will be on the right.

From Tappan Zee & The Saw Mill Pkwy, take 287 E. then take the Hutchinson River Pkwy. S. (Exit 9S), get off at Exit 25 and take a right at the bottom of the ramp, the Golf Course will be on your right.

Just 35 min. from Brewster, 25 min. from Norwalk, 35 min. from Peekskill, and 40 min. form NYC.

PLEASE DON'T FORGET TO R.S.V.P. YES NOW, EVEN IF YOU'RE A MAYBE!

Thank You!

.
results.how_to_find_us: PLEASE R.S.V.P. YES NOW, EVEN IF YOU'RE A MAYBE AND TRY TO HAVE EXACT CHANGE AT THE DOOR, THANK YOU!
results.name: PARTY TIL YOU FALL! @ NORTH STREET TAVERN  *MULTI*GROUP*EVENT*

results.name: PARTY TIL YOU FALL! @ NORTH STREET TAVERN  *MULTI*GROUP*EVENT*

results.description:
Full-Field Soccer - 11 v 11 - Large Goals - Casual but grueling games. We are all here to have fun, which means no slide tackling :). Want to keep it as co-ed as possible. If you are completely new to soccer, come join, just let us know.

**** NEW RULE **** - Game Time Officially Starts at 8:15. If you are not on the field ready to play, or are literally changing to play, your spot MAY BE GIVEN AWAY to a member on the wait.list if they show up.

(1) we are keeping an 11 v 11 game, with 1 substitute per side. We will rotate new players in every 10 minutes.

(2) Please only RSVP if you will come. No shows ruin the game for everyone on the field, as well as those who would have come and played in your spot.

(3) Please arrive on time. All games begin promptly at 8:15pm. This should give any late comers 15 minutes to arrive in case you get stuck and time to warm up.

(4) Games will be 30-40 minute halves. We will switch sides at the break. 

5/11/15 - NEW RULES

• Attendance will now be taken by myself personally when handing out the bibs. If you are a NO SHOW, you will be removed from the group and banned permanently. 99% of you have smart phones and can cancel their RSVP within 2-3 hours giving anyone on the wait list the chance to come and play.

• If you are on the wait list and come to the field, and a no show occurs, by 8:15 you will be given their spot.

Fee is $3.00 for the night. Permit cost me $1200 for the season, I'm not out to make money.

Get on 95 S. to 287 W. (Exit 21) then take the Hutchinson River Parkway S. (Exit 9S), get off at Exit 25 and take a right at the bottom of the ramp, the Golf Course will be on your right.

You can also get on the Merit Parkway which turns into the Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off exit 25.

From Danbury, take 684 S. to Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off at Exit 25, at the end of the ramp take a right and the Golf Course will be on the right.

Just 30 min. from Norwalk, 40 min. Danbury, and 20 min. from Stamford.

~From NEW YORK~

From Points North, take 684 S. to Hutchinson River Pkwy. and get off at Exit 25, at the end of the ramp take a right and the Golf Course will be on the right.

From Tappan Zee & The Saw Mill Pkwy, take 287 E. then take the Hutchinson River Pkwy. S. (Exit 9S), get off at Exit 25 and take a right at the bottom of the ramp, the Golf Course will be on your right.

Just 35 min. from Brewster, 25 min. from Norwalk, 35 min. from Peekskill, and 40 min. form NYC.

PLEASE DON'T FORGET TO R.S.V.P. YES NOW, EVEN IF YOU'RE A MAYBE!

Thank You!

.

results.description:
Ethical Brew is proud to present Live In Concert:

“COFFEEHOUSE OF THE ABSURD”

An Evening of Musical Satire Featuring the Comedic Wit of MIKE AGRANOFF & JOHN FORSTER

A portion of this performance will be donated "Autism Speaks" 

Mike Agranoff and John Forster


“Coffeehouse of the Absurd” is an evening of intelligent and satiric comedy featuring Mike Agranoff and John Forster. In case you don’t know John, he obviously fell asleep one too many times as a child listening to his Tom Lehrer albums.  This is evidenced by his twisted sense of humor, his delightfully skewed view of the human condition, and his prodigious skills as a pianist. His songs have a knack for taking the plausible but improbable, and leading that to its implausible but inevitable conclusion, by way of unlikely rhymes, horrible puns and ironic satire.  Together with the comedic wit of skilled troubadour, Mike Agranoff, they do a round-robin type show that is guaranteed to leave their audience in stitches!

Mike Agranoff

About Mike Agranoff

Equally at home in the contemporary and traditional camps of the folk world, Mike Agranoff is a fine musician and storyteller. His prime instrument is the guitar, upon which he shines with intricate fingerstyle arrangements of anything from Tin Pan Alley tunes of the 20s to fiddle tunes to his own music. He also plays concertina, piano, banjo, or sings acapella.  He can be uproariously funny, contemplative, and powerfully emotional in the space of a few minutes. Mike considers himself a “songfinder,” taking great delight in discovering little-known hidden gems and polishing them with his own distinctive style until they shine. Not only a performer, Mike is involved in presenting folk music as well, and is affiliated with The Folk Project, New Jersey’s oldest and largest folk music organization.

The buzz about Mike

"If you're tired of the endless stream of singer/songwriters whose main goal in life seems to be MTV, check out this clever...veteran New Jersey musician/storyteller."

Dirty Linen 

"You will never think of Folk Music the same after you attend a Mike Agranoff concert. Quite possibly the most reverent irreverent musician on the planet, Mike is absolutely irrepressible as he turns that genre inside out and back again in the blink of a twinkling eye. His parodies are legendary for their groan factor and insightful brilliance, but Mike is just as apt to restore an ancient heartfelt tune to its original splendor with his artful and deft guitar work. Mike Agranoff has been described as a “jokester-folkster” but that is just a part of his appeal. His eclectic love of all things musical is impossible to conceal. "

Flying Cat Music

"That guy's a genius!"

Christine Lavin

"Thanks to you for such an incredible night! I received so many wonderful comments, many from our board members, and everyone loved the show. I personally thought you gave a stellar performance - your choice of songs and stories was very well put together, very diverse and well crafted."

Ron Olesco, WFDU-FM, Hurdy Gurdy Folk Club

To learn more about Mike, visit www.mikeagranoff.com

John Forster

JOHN FORSTER is an award-winning songwriter, humorist and record producer whose work encompasses the worlds of singer-songwriter, musical theater and children’s entertainment. His 1994 debut album, “Entering Marion”, earned him an Indie Award HM for Best Comedy Album. Many of his witty, topical songs have been featured on NPR’s “Morning Edition”.  John’s songs have been recorded by Christine Lavin, Judy Collins, Rosanne Cash and the late Dave Van Ronk among others.  As a writer and producer of music for children, he has been nominated for four Grammy Awards, most recently for the Tom Chapin album,” Some Assembly Required.”  John’s musicals include scores for regional theater as well as On and Off-Broadway productions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nmKWJMENMxE&feature=player_embedded

The Buzz about John:

If Joni Mitchell and Daffy Duck had a love child, he’d probably write songs just like JOHN FORSTER. His sharply observed satires range from sheer slapstick to Jon Stewart acute.

Scott Alarik - The Boston Globe

JOHN FORSTER looks like an Episcopalian minister, but sings with adder tongue...A laser-swift wit, glinting with irony...One of the sharpest musical satirists around.

J. Rudolf Abate - The Free Press

JOHN FORSTER has claimed the satirical crown long abandoned by Tom Lehrer.  He's one very funny songwriter.

Rich Warren - Sing Out! Magazine

You don’t need me anymore. Now you’ve got JOHN FORSTER to kick around.

Tom Lehrer - Harvard Magazine

FORSTER has the world view of George Carlin, the musical-parody chops of Frank Zappa in his glory days, musically and lyrically clever in ways that AI Yankovic can only dream about.

For more info on John, visit www.johnforster.com

Have questions about Ethical Brew is proud to present Live in Concert: MIKE AGRANOFF & JOHN FORSTER?

Contact Ethical Brew

Coffeehouse of the Absurd is an evening of intelligent and satiric comedy featuring Mike Agranoff and John Forster.

results.description:
Our last Quiet Clubbing Party had over 400 members attend!

These parties have been written up in the NY Post, Daily News & featured on TV. If you've been to this Meetup before, then you already know how much fun it is. If not, come see what you've been missing! 

Tickets are just $10 for 1st 10 members w/ discount code "quiet" - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/quiet15/dates/Oct-03-2015_at_0900PM

How does it work?

You'll get a special wireless headset that will allow you to tune into one of 3 DJ's spinning at the same time.

DJ 1 – Top 40, 2K, 90s, 80s, Dance 
DJ 2 – Reggae, Reggaeton, Cumbia 
DJ 3 – Salsa, Merengue, Bachata 

What's included?

• $5 Shots, $6 Wines all night long 

• $4 Beer Specials until 11pm 

• 3 DJs spinning a mix of different music

• 2 bars & 2 floors of dance music

• 1 Quiet Events Headset Rental to party

• FREE Prizes & Giveaways for everybody

• FREE Shot for all this month's Birthdays

Are there Ice Breakers?

Everyone will receive half a playing card at the door 
Find other half & bring it to the bar for a FREE shot

How do we mingle?

It’s super social!  Just lower the volume or take the headphones off.  No loud music to talk over.

What does it cost?

First 10 tix are $10 w/ discount code "quiet"at this link - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/quiet15/dates/Oct-03-2015_at_0900PM

$15 after that online , $20 at the door w/ RSVP, $25 w/o 

Check out this video from a recent party - 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HmFLSpLOXvo

Is this event private?

The entire venue will be 100% private for our party.  Members can invite guests to join us.

Is there a dress code or age restriction?

No sweats, hats, etc  Jeans ok.  Dress stylish. This event is not age or ethnic specific.

Can I come alone?

Most come on their own.  If you don't know anyone, the ice breakers will help you meet other members.  So come alone or bring a friend or two - either way you will feel comfortable and have a great time.

Why does your RSVP say +99? 

This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees.  200+ members will be attending - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/quiet15/dates/Oct-03-2015_at_0900PM

What's included?

• $5 Shots, $6 Wines all night long 

• $4 Beer Specials until 11pm 

• 3 DJs spinning a mix of different music

• 2 bars & 2 floors of dance music

• 1 Quiet Events Headset Rental to party

• FREE Prizes & Giveaways for everybody

• FREE Shot for all this month's Birthdays

Are there Ice Breakers?

Everyone will receive half a playing card at the door 
Find other half & bring it to the bar for a FREE shot

It’s super social!  Just lower the volume or take the headphones off.  No loud music to talk over.

What does it cost?

Limited $10 online tickets via this link below:

$15 after that online and $25 at the door

Is this event private?

The entire venue will be 100% private for our party.  Members can invite guests to join us.

No sweats, hats, etc  Jeans ok.  Dress stylish. This event is not age or ethnic specific.

Can I come alone?

Most come on their own.  If you don't know anyone, the ice breakers will help you meet other members.  So come alone or bring a friend or two - either way you will feel comfortable and have a great time.

group.name: #1 NYC Singles Group - Meet, Mix, & Mingle

results.description:
Quiet Clubbing Singles Party!  (Must Pre-Pay Online)

Get tickets at: http://www.ClickMixers.com/quietclubbing.html
Tickets are just $15 for the first 10 people in this group that sign up (Must use discount code QUIETMEETUP at checkout to get this deal). THIS IS A PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO TICKETS WILL BE SOLD AT EVENT DOOR. 

THE RSVP LIST ON THIS PAGE IS ONLY A SMALL PORTION OF ACTUAL EVENT ATTENDEES. OVER 200 SINGLES WILL BE ATTENDING FROM MANY DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUPS AND ALSO SINGLES FROM OUTSIDE OF MEETUP WILL BE ATTENDING.

THIS IS NOT AN  ASIAN SPECIFIC EVENT. ALL ARE WELCOME TO ATTEND.

Our past Quiet Clubbing parties have been written up in the NY Post, Daily News & featured on TV.   If you've been to this party before, then you already know how much fun it is.  If not, come experience what everyone is talking about!

How does it work?

You'll get a special wireless headset that will allow you to tune into one of 3 DJ's spinning at the same time.

DJ 1 spins today's dance music (Top 40, Hip Hop, EDM, etc) 
DJ 2 spins 80's & 90's music (Pop, Rock, Old School, etc) 
DJ 3 spins ethnic music (Salsa, Bachata, Reggae, etc)

What's included?

• $5 Shots, $6 Wines all night long (at main level bar)

• $4 Beer Specials until 11pm (both bars)

• 3 DJs spinning a mix of different music

• 2 bars & 2 floors of dance music

• 1 Quiet Events Headset Rental to party

• FREE Prizes & Giveaways for everybody

• FREE Shot for all Birthdays That Fall In This Month

Are there Ice Breakers?

Everyone will receive half a playing card at the door 
Find other half & bring it to the bar for a FREE shot

How do we mingle?

It’s super social!  Just lower the volume or take the headphones off.  No loud music to talk over.

What does it cost?

Tickets are just $15 for the first 10 people in this group that sign up (Must use discount code QUIETMEETUP at checkout to get this deal). THIS IS A PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO TICKETS WILL BE SOLD AT EVENT DOOR. Get tickets at: http://www.ClickMixers.com/quietclubbing.html

Is this event private?  The entire venue will be 100% private for our party.  Members can invite guests to join us.

Is there a dress code or age restriction?  No sweats, hats, etc  Jeans ok.  Dress stylish. This event is not age or ethnic specific.

Can I come alone?  Most come on their own.  If you don't know anyone, the ice breakers will help you meet other members.  So come alone or bring a friend or two - either way you will feel comfortable and have a great time.

How many people are attending? This is a multi-Meetup group event.  This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees.  We will have 200+ members attending.

Tickets are just $15 for the first 10 people in this group that sign up (Must use discount code QUIETMEETUP at checkout to get this deal). THIS IS A PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO TICKETS WILL BE SOLD AT EVENT DOOR. Get tickets at: http://www.ClickMixers.com/quietclubbing.html

results.description:
Hi everyone, please note this is an open event being run by one of our Brit Meetup hosts Dawn. She throws a great party so hope you can make it along. Enjoy!

More info:


New York City’s Subway Soul Club has kept fans of Soul music shaking their tail feathers since 2001, featuring nationally and internationally renown DJs spinning Northern Soul, Motown and Sixties Go-Go records.

This event will have a British theme--all of our guests will be top Northern Soul DJs coming all the way from the UK!!

https://scontent.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xpt1/v/t1.0-9/11825937_989612311060061_8009402710601519846_n.jpg?oh=368dffa6e09c704f6d30dd7947d852f3&oe=5669F3E1

Special guest Val Palmer, resident DJ at London's most celebrated Northern Soul All-Nighter 'The 100 Club', will head-up a team of amazing British DJs including Warren Boogaloo (Boogaloo Soul Club) and Subway Soul Club co-founder Jeff Valle. They will spin original 45s from their own collections.


We've been trying for YEARS to arrange to bring these incredible soul DJs over for a UK night and we are so excited we can finally make it happen! So don't miss out. You may wait years for another opportunity to dance to the brilliant 45s played by these fine DJs—or fly to London to do so!


Of course it wouldn't be Subway Soul Club if we didn't have resident DJ Phast Phreddie the Boogaloo Omnibus also playing records, a gorgeous wooden dance floor and a big screen projecting images from the Sixties. Plus, Brit hostess with the mostest Lady Dawn will be meeting and greeting in all her Mod finery. You should wear yours, too.


This Subway Soul Club event, presented in association with our friends at Cavestomp, will take place at Lucille’s Bar & Grill, located in the legendary B.B. King’s Blues Club—famous for its live performances of such soul greats as Aretha Franklin, Darlene Love and James Brown! Lucille's also offers ample comfortable seating and you can even dine before you dance. Look out for drinks specials at the bar!

So get your dancing shoes on and join The Subway Soul Club for this unique opportunity to dance to the UK's top Northern Soul DJs here in New York!

SUBWAY SOUL CLUB – Brit Night Special!


Dance ’til dawn to the fabulous sounds of Sixties Soul records played by top DJs from London!

Entry ONLY $7 (advance) $10 on the door

Advanced Tickets

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/subway-soul-club-british-night-special-dance-all-night-to-1960s-northern-soul-motown-and-organ-tickets-17201921410?aff=es2

Discounted drinks specials.

Come early to ensure yourself a place on the dance floor. Doors open 9:30pm. Dancing starts at 10:00 PM!!!

Subway Soul Club: Look sharp! Dance hard!

results.description:
This film finds director Wes Craven in a transitional phase between his hard-hitting early work and his later commercial successes. As such, Deadly Blessing is an "all over the map" experience for viewers. The script veers back and forth between shock setpieces and an earnest exploration of religious repression, never truly committing to its genre until the last thirty minutes. At that point, it goes haywire with more than a few bizarre plot twists and a shock coda that feels tacked on. That said, Deadly Blessing is quite watchable for Craven fans despite these problems. The schizoid nature of the story ensures that it never becomes dull and the film distinguishes itself from the pack by offering a storyline that focuses on female characters and allows them to drive the plot. In terms of acting, Maren Jensen's lead performance is a bit flat at times but she gets nice support from Susan Buckner as a resourceful friend and Jeff East as a young sect member who finds his burgeoning adulthood bringing him into conflict with his religion. There are also scene-stealing turns by Ernest Borgnine as a brimstone-minded religious leader and Lois Nettleson as an eccentric neighbor (trainspotters will also notice a young Sharon Stone in there as Jensen's other gal-pal). Best of all, Wes Craven directs his unusual narrative with confidence, giving it a distinctive "American gothic" atmosphere and handling a number of creepy setpiecies with great skill: highlights include a skin-crawling nightmare involving a spider and a tense sequence where a snake slips into Jensen's bathtub while she isn't looking. In short, Deadly Blessing might be a mixed bag but its got enough eccentricities and stylish flourishes to make it worthwhile for fans of vintage horror.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q5bagblnFSY

results.description:
I know I have done this several times before so I am challenging those have come previously to complete two Black Courses & at least one Double Black Courses, but you can do at your own pace if this is your first time. 


This park is an exciting aerial forest adventure that provides a variety of courses that are fun for all ability levels. After participants are fitted with harnesses, they are led through a safety and park usage demonstration, fitted with gloves and are then free to navigate their chosen treetop courses. With eleven courses of varying difficulties (think ski trails; yellow, green, blue, black and double black), you are challenged to cross bridges, climb ladders, obstacles and zip lines. The park is built to meet the standards of the Association of Challenge Course Technology (ACCT).

- No previous experience is needed
- 11 separate courses and 162 platforms
- Over 40 zip lines
- 2 courses feature 2000' zip lines

Depart Date: October 4th Sunday. Please arrive 15 minutes earlier. We will depart sharp on time. (Event Time: 9:30 AM- 1:00 PM)

Depart 6:00 AM: [masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 (Outside Sheraton LaGuardia East Hotel) (Map)

Depart 6:40 AM: Northwest corner of 43rd St and 9th Ave New York, NY 10036 (Garden City Deli) (Map)

Return: Depart from Catamount after lunch around 3 PM, and get back NYC around 5:30 PM & Flushing 6:00 PM.

Cost: Early Birds $69 for first 10 spots or 21 days in advance; afterward $79. 

Includes: 3 hours Admission to Adventure Park & round trip luxury van transportation.

Lunch: We can have lunch together nearby afterward (members pay separately at restaurant).

Buy Ticket Here: http://oct2015catamount.eventbrite.com/ You can also Chase Quickpay me at [masked] to avoid transaction fee. (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) If Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location (Manhattan or Flushing). Your spot is NOT secured unless your payment is received.

Refund Policy: 

* Full refund minus $10 processing fee if cancelled on or before 21 days prior to the event date; 
* Afterward, no refund for cancellation or no show; however, spots can be transferred to your friends with $10 processing fee.

results.description:
Registration includes a T-shirt, race bib and timing chip, dog-tag finisher’s medal, sponsor gifts, and entry to a post-race festival with activities, music, and refreshments. Down & Dirty Obstacle Race presented by Subaru.

Covering oneself in mud, clambering up a jungle gym, and crawling through a tunnel is not how most people spend their Sunday mornings. But for competitors in the Down & Dirty Obstacle Race Presented by Subaru, it’s business as usual. 

During a three- or six-mile run, participants test their endurance and strength as they tackle more than 20 challenges in between sprints. These include leaping over marine hurdles, walking across balance beams, and clenching your teeth until tiny wings sprout from your ankles.

Youngsters can join in on the fun, too—the Adventure Kids course pits ages 4–13 against child-sized obstacles and a mud pit. Following the race, winners in their division earn awards, then celebrate during a post-race after-party.

results.description:
Winner stays, guys!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3XviR7esUvo

And just in case anyone needs a refresher, some guidance from Coach Ted Lasso.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KeG_i8CWE8

No refunds or credits will be offered. Please be 100% sure that you can attend before you RSVP.

Please have a fun, positive, and supportive attitude. Pass the ball to your teammates and have a good time. NO rough playing, slide tackling, or screaming at others will be tolerated. You'll be removed from the game immediately.

No cleats are allowed. Let's do our part to preserve the field. Turf or running shoes are recommended.

Always bring a *dark and white* t-shirt

Be on time.

Teams are broken out ahead of each game based on skill level. Beginner, intermediate, and advanced players are all encouraged to join.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

How to get to Queens West Sportsfield.

Queens West Sportsfield is located at:

5th Street between 47th Avenue & 46th Road, Long Island City


From Grand Central it's 3 minutes/1 stop on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.

From Queensboro it's 3 minutes/3 stops on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.

results.description:
THE GAME

Informal Meet Up. 8 vs 8. 2 subs per team. No Permit. Be warned - there may or may not be a permitted event at the location which could cancel our game.

Bring a white and black t-shirt, and good attitude.

This game is ideally for intermediate to advanced players, not for beginners.

RSVP GUIDELINES. IMPORTANT:

- If you RSVP and don't show, you'll be benched from this group for the next two weeks. - If you can't make it, Un RSVP, to give others a chance to play.

- If you didn't RSVP or are on the Waitlist, you're at the bottom of the line.

PLAY GUIDELINES

- No slide tackles.

- Respect your teammates and opponents.

- If you fight, you will be banned from the group, permanently.

- If you dribble more than you pass - you annoy everybody and will be banned from the group.

POSITIONS:

Being a pick up game, there are no permanent positions. If you've been playing forward for half the game and someone who's been playing the back line wants to play up front, give up your position and play some defense. When your team lose the ball, don't just stand and watch. Please support your teammates by get back on your side and play some defense.

Thanks.

Using Dive Computers: To help familiarize you with how Underwater Dive Computers work, use the following links: Introduction to Dive Computers. (There is a nominal fee) Using an Underwater computer is one of the safest ways to dive today. Computers are relatively inexpensive and very reliable. Putting the tools you need to complete a safe and fun dive right in your hand. Enroll and complete online course, when finished printout and bring us the results/certificate."Introduction to Dive Computers Link"

Why Buy My Own Equipment? Diving more than most other sports requires reliable equipment and instruction on its proper use. Don’t listen to an inexperienced expert or be fooled by the online hype, you get the best gear right here, from the people you can trust. 

EQUIPMENT: You are responsible for having all the gear you need to dive this weekend. Arrange equipment rentals with the shop.and pick up any rental equipment you will need. You will be wearing a thicker wetsuit, which you must try on to ensure proper fit. Purchasing Neoprene gloves is also highly recommended. Scuba Gear required for Certification Dives.

results.description:
WHAT:   NYC Dads Group highlight the benefits of babywearing for International Babywearing Week at the Bronx Zoo with Baby Bjorn along with other City Dads Groups across the nation.


LOCATION:   Meet-up at the Bronx Zoo together with your family for a hot breakfast, a brand new Baby Bjorn Carrier One, a brief info session, and a short Autumn walk with NYC Dads Group to enjoy the amazing animal exhibits at the well-known and spectacular zoo.

MEETING SPOT: meeting inside the Bronx Zoo at Schiff Family Great Hall by Southern Blvd Gate 

DATE:            Sunday, October 4, 2015


TIME:              9:45am – 11:30am

Cost:               **Each participating dad will receive FREE admission to the Bronx Zoo along with 2 other family guests (children under age 3 are Free) + free parking + a Baby Bjorn Baby Carrier

For:                  Dads with little ones between ages 0 - 3 years old 

Participants:  We only have room for 22 NYC Dads Group members along with their families 

-- Social Media - Hashtags: #IBW2015 and if room,  #wherewewear

Handles: @BabyBjornUS, @NYCDadsgroup (On Instagram, use @BabyBjorn_US)

--Dads will receive their Baby Bjorn Carrier on site at the breakfast and be properly fitted by a Baby Bjorn carrier professional. After a brief information session on benefits of babywearing, some photos will be taken. Finally, after formal meet & greet and photos conclude around 11:30am, dads will have freedom to enjoy the Bronx Zoo together with their families

Dads,


This is another meet-up opportunity that you're not going to want to miss! International Babywearing Week (IBW) (Oct 4  - 10) is a focused opportunity to celebrate, promote, and advocate the many benefits of Babywearing.  To celebrate IBW, BABY BJORN has offered to sponsor our meet-up by offering baby carriers to dads with little ones between ages 0 (newborn) - 3 years of age.

Our meetup will be during the "official IBW Week."  Baby Bjorn has generously agreed to provide 22 dads with a FREE** (expectations mentioned below) BABY CARRIER.  If you're up for an invigorating meet-up that involves breakfast and a Fall babywearing walk with some other cool, active, nurturing dads and their families, please join us! Additionally, you'll be a part of our national multi-city, event with City Dads Group members gathering, walking, or hiking in other major metropolitan cities across the U.S.


A Few guidelines and expectations for you to participate:

* Please RSVP for this meet-up ONLY if you are serious about attending as we will definitely have a waiting list. 

**To participate:

· You must be a NYC Dads Group member (this is a members only event)

· You will receive the baby carrier on site at the Bronx Zoo


· **You agree to take at least three photos during the meet-up event with camera or smartphone to be uploaded by you to the meet-up site OR preferably your social media sites like Twitter, Instagram, or FaceBook and tag @BabyBjornUS and @NYCDadsGroup using hashtag: #wherewewear. Also, adding a brief comment in the meetup site after the event sharing specific feedback about the event/baby carrier.

**Full Disclosure** NYC Dads Group have been compensated by Baby Bjorn for this International Babywearing Week event.  We're proud to work with brands that make products and provide services that we believe in and use ourselves.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

International Babywearing Week – October 4-10, 2015

IBW website - http://babywearinginternational.org/events/international-babywearing-week/

IBW FB - https://www.facebook.com/babywearinginternational

results.description:
Did you forget to sing? Perhaps after Third Grade, when the peer pressure set in. Perhaps someone picked out the "Gifted and Talented" - and it wasn't you. Or maybe the Nuns made you sing "God Bless America" and someone laughed. Or you were one of the "Blue Birds" - you moved your mouth but didn't make any sound. Or did you sing beautifully in that Elementary School play? Was it the Middle School chorus, where the boys were thrown out and it ended up a Girls Club that made a sound in three parts, so beautiful nothing to this day has extinguished that feeling? Perhaps you were one of the guys who made harmony in the reverb of the Boys Room, or in the audience at the concert, or the sports stadium, or in the shower?

Or maybe you played an instrument that kept your mouth busy, and you never did get the chance to sing? Was it the race of competition for excellence in something, something else, that left you no time?

Was is the implicit warning, between the lines of the praises of privilege, that you should not express yourself? Did you forget that feeling of camaraderie and being a part of something bigger than yourself? Did you forget that amazement you felt at yourself being able to memorize a large piece and give it your all - weeks and months of practice that lead to a performance, or several, that made you feel powerful, hopeful, inspired and you had drawn upon that experience to guide your life? You had that moment, lifted by the magic of the "ordered progression though time and space," that made life so rich, so romantic, so filled with spirit.

And then did you forget?

Forget that feeling, that high, that experience of joy and sadness, playing the part, being a messenger, a vessel. You forgot that there are scientific studies praising the participation in music and art, the health benefits, the raised white blood cell count, the relaxation response, the breathing, the healing power of sound, or just the old saying, "singing is good for you."

Now you have another chance.

Don't miss it.
results.name: Did You Forget to Sing?

results.description:
“…to be successful in life you need values, you need integrity, you need a vision, you need energy, and you need dynamism. And spirituality is the one thing that gives it all to you. If you are healthy, you can see better, you can eat better, you can speak better, you can hear better and you can run better. All this depends on just one thing. Similarly that which enriches your spirit is so essential to enrich all other aspects of life.” -Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, Founder, Art of Living Foundation

Whatever we do in life, it is all directed towards being happy. Why do we even do some service to somebody? It is because it gives some happiness to us. So anything we do in our life is directed towards achieving happiness, greater happiness, and even greater happiness. That’s how the mind goes. Yet, are we happy? Yes, some times. But often not!

This free seminar examines what comes in the way of our happiness. There will be a discussion on tools that can lead us to happiness – tools that every human being is privileged to learn and use. Come, relax, refresh and smile.

results.description:
Finally. After much begging and pleading by my loyal game players, it's time to play Flag football. Hut, hut, hike!

If you don’t know, now you know…

Flag football is a version of American football where the basic rules of the game are similar to those of the mainstream game, but instead of tackling players to the ground, the defensive team must remove a flag or flag belt from the ball carrier ("deflagging") to end a play. The emphasis of the game is its recreational, non-contact nature.  We all have good-paying jobs that we need to return to on Monday morning without injury, so anyone looking to channel their inner Lawrence Taylor should find another game to play in. This game is all skill level and gender friendly, so women and those with two left feet and ten thumbs are encouraged to join.

The game can be played a number of ways and the rules of my specific event will be explained before we play, but I base my rules on the WAKA league playing guide. Take a read before game time HERE.

A $3.00 organization fee will be collected at this event, your host is in the running for hardest working person on meetup.

The important stuff...

• This is a co-ed game so ladies don't be shy to sign up. And it doesn't matter if you have no athletic ability; you just have to be willing to have a little fun.

• Dress for physical activity! You'll be running A LOT so wear your sneaks, shorts and a t-shirt. Cleats are NOT allowed.

• Bring BOTH a black and white t-shirt. This is how we differentiate teams.

• Rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup.

• Check the meetup site before leaving for last minute
updates as well as my mobile phone number.

• No guests allowed to play. You can bring a friend to spectate though if you need to hear the roar of the crowd.

• Please DO NOT RSVP if you do not seriously plan to attend as space is limited. No flakes allowed! If you RSVP and I notice that you have a number of no shows or have a history of last minute cancellations, you will be removed.

results.description:
Edible wild plants are growing right at your feet, in our city parks, as “weeds” in gardens and yards, even in abandoned parking lots. You just need to know where to look and how to safely identify and sustainably harvest them. Leda will show you how to spot wild edibles such as blackberries, pineapple weed, wild “cardoons”, daylily blossoms and many more untamed culinary delights. You’ll learn how to sustainably harvest and then deliciously prepare these wild, seasonal ingredients. 

Leda will show you how to find free food that’s safe to eat and growing all around you. She’ll explain techniques for collecting wild plants ways that are beneficial to the ecosystems you are harvesting from. She’ll also introduce you to the medicinal uses of many wild plants. Wear comfortable walking shoes, bring drinking water and a way to take notes and photos. Leda will then explain the flavors of wild ingredients and how to prepare them, as well as tips on how to preserve them for year-round use.

More info and tickets here - https://goo.gl/oSupk9

results.description: 8 - 10 miles, moderate pace, multiple opportunities to drop off.  Explore the neighborhoods that nurtured and were celebrated by three distinguished Brooklyn writers:  Williamsburg (Betty Smith, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn), Bedford Stuyvesant (Paule Marshall, Brown Girl, Brownstones), and Brownsville (Alfred Kazin, A Walker in the City).  We will begin in Williamsburg and end in Brownsville, visiting homes, schools, churches, synagogues, libraries, and parks as we walk the streets brought vividly to life in these autobiographical novels and memoirs.  Readings from the books will mark each stop along the way.  Call or email the leader, Joyce Zonana, [masked],[masked], for meeting place and time anytime on Saturday (10/3) until 10 pm.  Nonmembers: $3. 10

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Platform program with Dr. Ruth Milkman, professor of sociology at the CUNY Graduate Center and at the Joseph F. Murphy Institute for Worker Education and Labor Studies, where she is also Academic Director.

 Dr. Milkman will discuss recent grassroots initiatives aimed at organizing New York City’s low-wage and immigrant workers. Her book includes critical analyses of thirteen worker centers, unions, and community-based campaigns focused on the new “precariat.” Some organize in traditionally non-union sectors like street vending, domestic work, and freelance “creative”fields; others focus on grocery store, retail and restaurant workers. These case studies help us understand the future prospects of labor in the context of New York’s growing inequality, and the work of revolutionizing communities from the bottom up.

Ruth Milkman is a sociologist of labor and labor movements who has written on a variety of topics involving work and organized labor in the United States, past and present. Recently she has written extensively about low-wage immigrant workers in the U.S., analyzing their employment conditions as well as the dynamics of immigrant labor organizing. She helped lead a multi-city team that produced a widely publicized 2009 study documenting the prevalence of wage theft and violations of other workplace laws in Los Angeles, Chicago and New York. 

Regular classes for Ethical Education for children today.
results.name: "New Labor" in New York

EVENT TYPE: Festival
COST: Free
DESCRIPTION:
The Medieval Festival brings to life the customs and spirit of the Middle Ages. Manhattan's Fort Tryon Park is transformed into a medieval market town decorated with bright banners and processional flags. Performers, guests and festival goers dress in medieval costume.

Visitors are greeted by authentic medieval music, dance, magic, and minstrels, as well as jugglers and jesters. The afternoon is concluded with a thrilling joust between four knights on horseback. Costumed vendors will be on hand to demonstrate and sell a wide variety of medieval crafts as well as food and drink.

This annual event in Fort Tryon Park is organized by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation and the Washington Heights Inwood Development Corporation; the park will be closed to all traffic. A limited number of parking spaces near The Cloisters will be available for mobility-impaired visitors. The Cloisters will offer tours of collection highlights and the gardens.

ATTRACTIONS:

• Medieval Costume
• Medieval Market Selling their Crafts
• Medieval Dance & Music
• Magic Tricks
• Live Entrainment By Jugglers and Jesters 
• Knights Jousting on Horsebacks

• Knights Jousting

• Magic Tricks

http://www.whidc.org/festival/home.html

results.description:
This run will be beginner-friendly, but we welcome runners at all levels. We will be running anywhere from 2 - 6ish miles depending on what everyone is looking to do. 

The main starting point will be at Columbus Circle by the gold statue (not the silver unisphere).

Here are some options:

Advanced: 
6 miles: Lots of hills. Run along the full outer loop of the park. The hills are more challenging if you run counter-clockwise. 

Intermediate: 
~5 miles: Run along the outer loop but cut across the 102nd st traverse.  You'll skip the infamous Harlem hill.

Beginner: 
1.7 miles: Run around the lower loop. Cut across the 72st traverse and hang a left again once you hit the west side, end back at Columbus Circle.

If possible we will break into pace groups, but either way lets meet back at the USS Maine Monument around 12-12:15am.

Where do I leave my stuff? 
The New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center (located on the 2nd floor) has open bins, and lockers behind the cash register. To use the lockers, you must bring your own lock. They also have changing rooms. These services are free. The New York Running Company opens at 11am on Sunday. 

What time does the run actually start?
Plan on arriving at 11am, but we won't start running until about 11:15am in case people need to change or drop off their stuff at the NY Running Company. We will not wait longer that 11:15am.  

What happens after the run?
After the run once everyone is together again, we can grab some food! Weather permitting, we can get something to eat from Whole Foods (or wherever you like), and we can sit and eat in the park. We can walk over to the Sheep Meadow.
If the weather is not picnic-friendly, we can hit our goto place which is Cosmic Diner on 52nd and 8th ave. Hot chocolate, coffee, pancakes? Mmmm.. If anyone wants to suggest a different place that is close by, we're flexible.


Call/text Henry at (646)[masked] if you have any questions or are having trouble finding us.

Dig deep and drag yourself out to go for a run! You'll be glad you did!

** only RSVP 'No' if you were previously a 'Yes'.

results.description:
http://www.nysec.org/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/images/Greenberg.jpg?itok=uyDlkZ-t Marc Greenberg, executive director of The Interfaith Assembly on Homelessness and Housing, and graduate of the Life Skills Empowerment program

Dr. Anne Klaeysen, Leader presides  

The Assembly is a coalition of religious organizations and individuals working with and on behalf of homeless, poorly housed, and at-risk individuals. It was founded in 1986 at the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine in NYC and addresses homelessness in two ways: by helping those who are homeless recover from the trauma associated with their homelessness and begin to rebuild their lives; and by working with our broad base of coalition partners in supporting the establishment of public policies that will produce and preserve housing affordable to homeless and lowest income New Yorkers and those that will provide needed services to those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.

Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

results.description:
With Curt Collier
NY Ethical Society Leader for Environmental Advocacy
The recent fight over the push to ban the incandescent light bulb is indicative of what is wrong with American views on environmentalism. Despite the overwhelming evidence that we need to ban these diminutive energy hogs many Americans cling to the bulb as yet another misguided symbol of the struggle against a supposedly overbearing government. What is really at the heart of this imprudent behavior and how can reframing this debate impact other needed changes as well.
results.name: Sunday Platform: How Many Americans Does It Take to Change a Lightbulb?

results.description:
Established in 1987, after lengthy grassroots efforts to preserve the area from development, the Pyramid Mountain Natural Historic Area is more than 1,500 acres of open space rich in natural and historical resources. Visitors to the park enjoy its environmental, natural, geological, and historical diversity.

Easily visible to hikers are the unusual geological attributes of Pyramid Mountain, such as Tripod Rock, a 160-ton boulder balanced atop three smaller rocks, known as a glacial erratic. The broad mountains, flat-topped ridges, and narrow valleys of Pyramid Mountain are not only beautiful, but also vital in feeding downstream reservoirs, supplying needed aquifers, and supporting flora and fauna.

The wide variety of natural habitats found within Pyramid Mountain include fields, forests, streams and ponds, which support a number of plants considered uncommon to New Jersey as well as threatened and endangered plants and animals. Historically, Pyramid Mountain is important for its lessons about the Lenape Indians, who flourished in this area, and the early European settlers, who came to the area to take advantage of its rich natural resources.

We are looking at a 3 hour hike with stops. We will have food after the hike at a local diner

results.description:
Another TGTSNBN tradition, the Medieval Festival at Fort Tryon Park is a FREE festival held every year in one of the cities most gorgeous parks.

Fort Tryon is actually fairly easy to get to.

One method is to take the A train to 190th street and make sure to take the elevators upstairs.

By bus you can take the M4 which drops you off right in front of the festival.

I recommend leaving EARLY if you taking the bus or the train. There is almost always weekend delays.  You don't want to miss any of the fun.

The Medieval Festival is DEFINITELY a costume encouraged event.  Many of our members either wear ren garb or HP cosplay.  Remember, this is always encouraged not required =)

Near the end of the day we traditionally meet at the upper level of the Cloisters to take photos in front of their iron gate.  This year shouldn't be any different =D

The website for the festival can be found here:

http://www.whidc.org/home.html
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet up at the entrance to the park right outside its subway station.

results.description:
Bonjour ! We will meander and talk (bien sur!) through Linden Terrace (the highest point in Fort Tryon Park and the second highest natural elevation in Manhattan, with great views of the Hudson and the city).
Then we'll visit the Cloisters where we can take a look at the famous Unicorn Tapestries (entre autres!) Afterwards, we'll walk through Inwood Hill Park, the largest forested area still remaining in Manhattan, and the only entirely undeveloped park (que des arbres!).
We'll finish our time travelling at....The 2015 Medieval Art Festival !http://www.whidc.org/festival/home.html

PLEASE NOTICE THAT :
-Admission to the Cloisters is "pay what you wish" -- $1 is fine). Buy lunch in the cafe in the Cloisters (around $10) or bring your own.
-Early out at Dyckman St. or by taking the #4 bus from the Cloisters.)
-The walk should end around 4 with a pause for refreshment at the Indian Road Cafe on 218 St. (near the 215 St. stop on the #1 subway).

DIRECTIONS ?
-Take the "A" train to 190 St. and then the elevator up to Fort Washington Ave. -- or take the #4 bus directly to 190 St. and Fort Washington Ave.
-If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, just please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Merci !

In case you need to reach me :[masked]/[masked]

A bientôt ! Alex

results.description: The Sunday School at the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County helps children aged 2-14 explore and develop their moral and critical thinking skills through fun and interactive lessons and field trips. We meet weekly at 11am on Sundays for 1.5 hours while the adults of the Ethical Culture Society are attending the platform meeting. Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. The Sunday School Graduation Rite of Passage, completed by our 8th graders, allows them to present to the community how their Sunday School experience has informed their moral and ethical development.
results.name: Sunday School at the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

group.name: The Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

results.description:
Speaker: Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner

Details: As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us. We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves. One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. 

More information: http://www.rysec.org/event/nurture-nature/?instance_id=2663

Join us for a more in-depth workshop at 1:30-4:30! 

About the Speaker: Birds have always called to LoraKim Joyner. Since an early age she always had birds in the home, out in the pigeon coop, or eating at the yard feeder. Her hope for avian flourishing led her to a B.S. in Avian Sciences and then later to a D.V.M. where she specialized in birds. A later Masters in Preventive Veterinary Medicine emphasized avian research. Hearing birds call to her heart, she worked in other countries as a consultant in avian medicine and conservation, with an emphasis on parrot conservation. Her hopes for the birds led her to the Philippines, Panama, Costa Rica, Mexico, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, and Guatemala where she lived for several years. Her work with birds has also included working as a Clinical Instructor and Research Assistant Professor at the Nondomestic Avian Clinic at the College of Veterinary Medicine, North Carolina State University. There she later served as the Community Advocate, where she taught ethics and grief management as well as assisted staff, faculty, and clients in dealing with grief and ethical issues. Leaving active veterinary practice behind, she entered the Unitarian Universalist ministry. She encourages Animal Blessings and Earth Celebrations in congregations and is the president of Unitarian Universalists for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (UFETA). She is seeking certification in Nonviolent Communication and is a Sufi Initiate. Today she serves as the minister of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of Gainesville, Florida. There she continues her healing work, for her experiences have taught her that the birds cannot flourish if the human heart cannot heal, and the human heart cannot heal without knowing the great depth of suffering and beauty in all life.

Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;

results.description:
UNLEASH YOUR HIDDEN POTENTIAL THROUGH ADVANCED MEDITATION TECHNIQUES!

WHAT IS SATSANG?

In Indian philosophy it means the company of the highest truth, the company of a guru, or company with an assembly of persons who listen to, talk about, and assimilate the truth. This typically involves listening to scriptures, reflecting on, discussing and assimilating their meaning, meditating on the source of these words, and bringing their meaning into ones's daily life.

WHAT IS MEDITATION?

Meditation is a practice in which an individual trains the mind or induces a mode of consciousness. In meditation one is able to experience the self which leads to a peaceful and stress free life; ultimately achieving bliss and tranquility through a balanced mind and healthy lifestyle!

Divya Jyoti Kendra (Divine Light Awakening Center) is a non-profit, non-denominational organization, which has been working globally towards one goal - To Help Humanity!
We believe raising humanity to a higher collective consciousness is the prime key to attaining global peace and a restored society.

Please join us for Spiritual Music, Discourses and Meditation every Sunday!

*Everything is FREE of cost. A vegetarian meal will be provided at the end. All are Welcome!!!

**Enter through the school yard**
results.name: Join us this Sunday at Satsang for spiritual discourses, music and meditation!

results.description:
Folks, 
Inviting volunteers to join me at the St Xaviers Church Welcome Kithcen on Sunday to serve over 1000 meals to the poor and homeless provided by St Xaviers Pantry.

This is based on the values that we would treat everyone equal,trustworthy, with dignity without any discrimination. We also want to be socially inclusive, including everyone with their preferences, culture and celebrate diversity. We will serve vegetarian dishes. The Soup Kitchen is dependent on volunteers to help work towards sustaining these values our community. If you are interested in being a volunteer, rsvp through this page. You don't have to be particularly skillful, we believe that if you have the passion, that's all that's needed :)


Soup Kitchen provides the aprons, gloves, hairnets. (one can wear their own baseball hat). Long hair need to be tied back unless it all fit in the hair net. We work with you, show you what to do. Please wear something comfortable.

Type of help could vary from coordinating the line, serving meals, Removing empty plates from the table or general helping out. 

Location -

 Church of St. Francis Xavier (Basement Hall)

46 W. 16th Street (Between 6th and 5th Avenue), New York, NY

Time -

11:30 - 3:30 ( You are required to stay till the end)

I will put my number on the meetup wall once we get close to the date. Members might get different responsibilities but will try to work as a group.

results.description:
Jazz for brunch anyone?

https://youtu.be/JMdyMGJY65I

We'll be brunching to the sounds of the Blue Jersey Band and their particular brand of gypsy jazz.

If you like Django Reinhardt or Stephane Grapelli -- or even if these names mean nothing to you, Blue Jersey's energetic swing will have you bouncing in your seat!



Directions  & Parking:

The coffee house we've graciously been offered as a venue is located inside the Union Train station, near Kean University. It's in an unmarked building, so it might be tough to spot from a distance. To help you find it, here's what it looks like from down the street.

In addition, here is an overhead map to help you get your bearings and familiarize yourself with the area.

If you're driving to the event, you can park in any open spot at no charge. At this hour, there is no parking enforcement.

If you are taking the train, the venue is right inside the Union Train station, which is on the Raritan Valley Line. Here's an NJ Transit Map of the rail system to help you figure out if taking the train would be convenient for you.

To Find Us:

Rock'n' Joe is a cozy place. You'll see us gathered around the stage on your left as soon as you walk in the front door. Grab a beverage or something to eat and come sit with us!

results.description:
The Medieval Festival brings to life the customs and spirit of the Middle Ages. Manhattan's Fort Tryon Park is transformed into a medieval market town decorated with bright banners and processional flags. Performers, guests and festival goers dress in medieval costume.

Visitors are greeted by authentic medieval music, dance, magic, and minstrels, as well as jugglers and jesters. The afternoon is concluded with a thrilling joust between four knights on horseback. Costumed vendors will be on hand to demonstrate and sell a wide variety of medieval crafts as well as food and drink.

The festival is free -- there are no charges for admission or entertainment. Donations at our wishing wells are welcome, however!

The festival is held in the area surrounding the world famous Cloisters, a magnificent museum of medieval art located in Fort Tryon Park near the northern end of Manhattan Island.

http://www.whidc.org/festival/home.html

The park offers vistas of the Hudson River and the picturesque Palisades: a setting reminiscent of Europe eight centuries ago.
results.name: Medieval Festival in Fort Tryon Park

results.description:
Life was tough in the Middle Ages, what with feudalism, the Crusades and that whole plague business. But it did have some cool aspects to commend it—like castles, Chaucer and pointy hats—which are celebrated at this annual throwback fair. Explore an anachronistic village in the area around the Cloisters, where you can listen to bards and minstrels, wash down a fire-roasted turkey leg with mead and watch riders unseat each other in a jousting tourney.

Additional info.

Now in its 31st year, the Medieval Festival has been attracting crowds of about 60,000 visitors to Fort Tryon Park in recent years.

The festival features knights who joust on horseback, a medieval marketplace and more than 100 costumed performers who juggle, perform traditional music and demonstrate the art of falconry.

The event was started by the Washington Heights and Inwood Development Corporation as a way to attract visitors to the neighborhood.

results.description:
This was in the draft section and it looks like fun, so let's do it again!


This is a FREE multi-opportunity photography event. If you missed last year's event, you'll definitely want to make this one. You can see photos people submitted from last year's event here:


http://www.meetup.com/New-Jersey-Photographers/photos/24962232/

The event is rain or shine. They setup a covered tent with plenty of seating. Last year's event was cloudy with tons of fog and a light rain and we still got great pics of the raptors.


------


We'll start with the Hawks on the Hudson where we'll be able to view birds of prey up close. From there, we get to go looking for wild raptors in the air as there's a chance to view hawks, eagles, and falcons during their migrations. 

We can take a break for lunch after the Hawks event and either visit the Lookout Inn or go to one of the many restaurants in nearby Fort Lee. 

For those who want to stay after lunch, we also have the opportunity walk the trails to photograph other parts of the Palisades Interstate Park including the George Washington Bridge and possibly the fall foliage. There's also a historic settlement with cannons and buildings overlooking the Hudson by the bridge lookout. 

The park also offers the opportunity to capture other various wildlife. 

Hawks on the Hudson

The Palisades Interstate Park in New Jersey hosts this annual NPC event featuring live birds of prey presented by the Delaware Valley Raptor Center. Between the programs, visitors will have a chance to see the animals up close, chat with the presenters, and to enjoy activities and exhibits by some of the member organizations of the NPC. The afternoon is free and open to all, with no advanced registration required to attend. Lookout Inn, a refreshment stand with a lunch and snack menu, as well as gifts and books, will be open during the event. Click here for directions.


Weather permitting, visitors will also be able to stop by an ongoing “hawk watch” only a few yards beyond the parking area — and 530 feet above the Hudson River. There they can try their luck at spotting wild raptors — hawks, eagles, and falcons — as they migrate south. Throughout the fall, volunteer observers congregate at the lookout point to identify the passing raptors, part of a continent-wide annual study conducted by the Hawk Migration Association of North America. All through September and October and into early November, the State Line hawk watch welcomes visitors who want to learn more about these magnificent animals. While an occasional eagle will glide by the lookout at eye-level, visitors will also learn how experienced observers use a combination of clues like silhouette and flight patterns to identify even those animals that pass hundreds of feet overhead—mere “specks” to the uninitiated—and visitors to the hawk watch are encouraged to bring binoculars with them if they can.

Photos from last year

This little guy was the crowd favorite:


Group Member Matthew Renk got this awesome shot of the GWB with the Fog:

UPDATE- 10/1

Contacted The Nature Program Cooperative at Palisades Park this morning. The program may be cancelled due to severe weather. Updates to follow.

UPDATE- 10/2

Received a call from the Nature Program Cooperative, the event has not been cancelled as of yet. The weather is looking better, but it will still be overcast with heavy clouds.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the State Line Lookout.
results.name: Photograph the GW Bridge, Fall Foilage, and View Hawks on the Hudson

The Freshkills Park Development Team welcomes the public to celebrate the new 3.2-mile New Springville Greenway with a festival. Join us for the ride, meet fellow bike commuters and enthusiasts, and take a walk along the scenic wetlands and spectacular views of Freshkills Park’s interior. Vendors will offer food and drink as well as activities and music.
Running the length of the eastern edge of Freshkills Park, the New Springville Greenway creates north/south bike access parallel with Richmond Avenue by adding new asphalt pavement, concrete sidewalk reconstruction and improvements, and associated drainage systems, and incorporating the most sustainable techniques in bio-swale design and construction.

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 12pm-3pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.
