results.description:
We invite you to meet and learn from one of the most important women and role models for everyone, Le Ly Hayslip, miracle worker and international ambassador for peace. If you can see the world as she does, then you can change it as she has.

Le Ly Hayslip authored two groundbreaking bestsellers, When Heaven and Earth Changed Places and Child of War, Woman of Peace, memoirs of her painful and ultimately triumphant journey from a tragic childhood in war-torn Vietnam to her new life in America, which Oliver Stone adapted into the third film in his Vietnam trilogy, “Heaven & Earth.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7yYV6k4t-Ec

The lecture, part of an east coast speaking tour, will take place at CRS on

Sunday, October 4, 2015 from 12 – 2 pm, with a reception to follow

.

Advanced tickets are available online, by phone and at CRS for $25 and at the door by donation. Seating is limited, but as long as there is space, no one will be turned away who cannot pay.

Buy tickets online:
http://bit.ly/1QbvQCI

Despite having scant resources at her disposal, she used her will and compassion to establish two foundations (East Meets West and, later, Global Village Foundation) to Heal the Wound of War. For 30 years, Le Ly has set up hospitals, orphanages, universities, schools, classrooms, libraries and training workshops all over Vietnam.

How has Le Ly accomplished so much? A twice widowed house cleaning lady with little formal education, Le Ly didn’t have any money, nor any influential family members. She changed the world by changing her mind.

She learned to accept her traumas, recognizing they put her on a path to learn, grow and progress, enabling her to contribute to the world far more than if she had remained in the rice paddies of her village. She transformed her experience into a narrative that could spark change and healing. She didn’t judge herself or place any limits on her potential but worked tirelessly to be of service as much as possible.

“I had a dream in my spirit to see us reunited again as people, if only I could break down the walls of fear and mistrust that divided us. I dreamed that I, a housewife with a third-grade education, could transform the hatred of war into a bridge of peace for all people.” — Le Ly Hayslip

Let’s hear her story, share her passion, and follow in her footsteps to create more and more miracles together.

More About Le Ly Hayslip

"In May 1970, I stepped from the Pan Am airliner that had taken me from the hell my country had become to the heaven I hoped America would be. I was twenty years old with two sons, both by different fathers. I didn’t speak much English, and my manners were better suited to peasant villages and Saigon street corners than a suburb of San Diego, which was to be my new home — a place stranger to a Vietnamese farm girl than the dark side of the moon.

"My background was not like that of my American neighbors. By age twelve I had lost two brothers and countless uncles, aunts, and cousins to the war. By age fifteen I had been in battle, captured, tortured, …condemned to death and raped….

"By sixteen I was an unwed mother supporting my family on Danang’ s black market. By the time I was nineteen my father had committed suicide rather than involve me again with the Viet Cong, and I was married to de quoc My, ”the enemy”—a middle-aged American civilian construction engineer, Ed Munro— in the desperate hope that would save me and my children from the war."

— Le Ly Hayslip, Child of War, Woman of Peace

In 1986, Le Ly returned to her native homeland, Vietnam, and was stunned by the devastation, poverty and illness left by the Vietnam and American War. She went to work.

She initiated a bridge building project to bring American veterans back to Vietnam to work with international volunteers and her countrymen to re-build the villages destroyed in the war, providing a long elusive path to reconciliation and peace of mind for countless soldiers and citizens from all sides of the conflict. Her efforts to educate people about post-war conditions in Vietnam and to create new peaceful ties between Americans and Vietnamese were instrumental in persuading the US to re-establish and normalize relations with Vietnam in 1995. In 2000 Le Ly joined a delegation accompanying then President Clinton on his historic trip to Vietnam, the first by an American president since the end of the war.

To acknowledge those who helped her healing the war and peacemakers throughout the world, she created a Bridge of Peace Awards Gala Ceremony to honor people like Oliver Stone, Ron Kovic, John McCain, John Kerry and many others.

results.description:
A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.

results.description:
We'd like to invite you to meet and learn from one of the most important women and role models for everyone, Le Ly Hayslip, miracle worker and international ambassador for peace. If you can see the world as she does, then you can change it as she has.

The lecture, part of an east coast speaking tour, will take place at CRS on Sunday, October 4, 2015 from 12 – 2 pm, with a reception with live Okinawan music to follow. Advanced tickets are available online, by phone and at CRS for $25 and at the door by donation. Seating is limited, but as long as there is space, no one will be turned away who cannot pay.

Le Ly Hayslip authored two groundbreaking bestsellers, When Heaven and Earth Changed Places and Child of War, Woman of Peace, memoirs of her painful and ultimately triumphant journey from a tragic childhood in war-torn Vietnam to her new life in America, which Oliver Stone adapted into the third film in his Vietnam trilogy, “Heaven & Earth.”

Despite having scant resources at her disposal, she used her will and compassion to establish two foundations (East Meets West and, later, Global Village Foundation) to Heal the Wound of War. She transformed her experience into a narrative that could spark change and healing. She didn’t judge herself or place any limits on her potential but worked tirelessly to be of service as much as possible.

“I had a dream in my spirit to see us reunited again as people, if only I could break down the walls of fear and mistrust that divided us. I dreamed that I, a housewife with a third-grade education, could transform the hatred of war into a bridge of peace for all people.” — Le Ly Hayslip

results.description:
Photography by Verena

Website: http://www.whidc.org/festival/home.html

The annual Medieval Festival in Fort Tyron Park (Northern Manhattan) is schedules for Sunday 10/4/15. Let's go back in time and enjoy the art, music, lifestyle and FOOD of the Middle Ages.


*****

How to get to the Cloisters:

By Subway/Bus
Take the A train to 190th Street and exit the station by elevator. Walk north along Margaret Corbin Drive for approximately ten minutes or transfer to the M4 bus and ride north one stop. If you are coming from the Museum's Main Building, you may also take the M4 bus directly from Madison Avenue/83rd Street to the last stop. (Please allow more time for this option.)

By Car
Take Henry Hudson Parkway northbound to the first exit after George Washington Bridge (Fort Tryon Park—The Cloisters). This exit is only accessible from the northbound lane; if coming from the north, take Henry Hudson Parkway southbound to exit 14–15, make a U-turn, and travel north one mile to the exit marked Fort Tryon Park—The Cloisters.

Parking

Visitors to The Cloisters may use free city parking available in Fort Tryon Park.

Weather permitting, we will meet at 12PM AT THE MAIN ENTRANCE of the Cloisters Museum. There are a couple of benches right next to the bus stop. I'll wait there.


*****

I suggest splitting up into smaller groups before entering the festival.  Be warned that it will be extremely crowded and most likely some of you will fall behind and get lost.  Don't worry, just enjoy the festival and take lots of photos. It ends at 6PM. There are plenty of stands for food, handcrafts, arts, etc. There is also a couple of tournaments you may want to watch. Be early at the tournament field, again it will be crowded! Click on the link above for their website to review the program and the map.

• Bring some snacks and water, or money to grab something to eat at one of the many food stands.


* There are four locations with toilets in the park. Check the map.

• Dress appropriate for the weather and wear comfy shoes.

• As always, please be on time. Allow yourself enough travel time and check the MTA for any subway updates. I won’t be able to take calls and messages after the meetup starts.

Details of this event may be added or changed at any time, so please check in periodically on this page.

If you have any questions, text me before the day of the event. Please make sure you identify yourself in your messages so I know who you are.


~ Sally 347.878.NYCP (6927)

********************

Disclaimer: Participation in these events requires that you assume all risks associated with these activities, and that the Organizers, Co-Organizers and Event Hosts are in no way liable for any loss or injury as a result of your participation. In other words, you are attending these events at your own risk!! For more details, please review our rules and disclaimers.

Meetup requires a semi-annual fee to organize and maintain the group's event page.  If you would like to send a contribution to help keep NYC Photographers up and running, you can send $2.00 or more via PayPal at [masked].  This is NOT a requirement, but any amount will be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

venue.name: A Train: 190th Street Subway Exit (Street Level)

results.description:
Field Trip - Fort Tryon Park Medieval Festival Sunday October 4, 2015, 12 Noon


The Medieval Festival brings to life the customs and spirit of the Middle Ages. Manhattan's Fort Tryon Park is transformed into a medieval market town decorated with bright banners and processional flags. Performers, guests and festival goers dress in medieval costume.

Visitors are greeted by authentic medieval music, dance, magic, and minstrels, as well as jugglers and jesters. The afternoon is concluded with a thrilling joust between four knights on horseback. Costumed vendors will be on hand to demonstrate and sell a wide variety of medieval crafts as well as food and drink.

The festival is free -- there are no charges for admission or entertainment. Donations at our wishing wells are welcome, however!

Join PWCC's Sorin Capota, <[masked]> and RSVP at right.  

Where should we meet? I think that we should meet on FORT WASHINGTON AVE. subway exit (on top of the hill). This is where the main park entrance is. Those who come by "A" train should take the elevator up and we'll meet at the Fort Washington exit of 190th Street "A" train station at 12 Noon.  We'll walk over to Margaret Corbin Circle/190th Street and Fort Washington Avenue. It will extend all the way around the world famous Cloisters, a magnificent Museum of Medieval art.


For more info, see: http://www.whidc.org/festival/home.html


We'll grab a bite and beverages after the trip.

The only charge for this event is a festival donation ($1 or more) and your dutch meal!

<a href="mailto:[masked]"></a>

results.description:
Green-Wood House Tour


Sunday, October 4, 12:00 pm - 6:00 pm open-house-tour


Don’t miss one of Green-Wood’s most popular events! For one day only, we’re opening many of our most impressive and elaborate mausoleums for public perusal. Peek inside massive stone slabs and elaborate iron-wrought doors as you step inside stunning examples of Green-Wood’s distinct architecture. This self-guided tour will include the Egyptian Revival tomb of John Taylor Johnston, an early president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the ornamental Nichols mausoleum which served as a kind of hostel for Nichols friends and family; the imposing mausoleum of the Dewey’s, a family of early American settlers; and several more . At each stop, “house” docents will offer a glimpse into the lives of the personalities who now rest in these opulent structures. Bring your sneakers and walk the route, or use the Green-Wood trolley for “Hop on, hop off” service between each site. A handy map, provided at the main entrance, will show the locations of each open house.


$15 for members of Green-Wood and BHS/$20 for non-members.

October 04,[masked]:00 pm— 5:00 pmAt


Orchard Street between Houston and Delancey


Pickle Day, you say? What on earth is PICKLE DAY?

We thought you’d never ask.


Pickle Day is a neighborhood wide celebration of all things pickled that takes place every autumn in New York’s Lower East Side. The streets come alive with internationally renowned picklers, local vendors, live music, and activities. This celebration of the great LES pickling tradition takes center stage for ONE DAY EVERY YEAR, drawing enthusiasts from ’round the globe to remember their pickled roots!

SAVE THE DATE FOR PICKLE DAY 2015: SUNDAY, OCT 4TH

PickleDay.nyc

Subway Take the F/J/M/Z to Essex Street
Walk West down Essex
Turn North at Orchard

results.description:
Let's watch the animals--camels, llamas, reindeer, yaks, monkeys, eagles, goats, pigs, foxes, roosters, kangaroos, and tortoises have appeared in past years--parade into Cathedral St. John the Divine on Amsterdam Ave. and W. 112th St. for their annual blessing on Saint Francis day. Then we'll  explore parts of Central Park that are off the beaten path--like the Ravine and North Woods. Next we'll walk west to visit some lovely community gardens outside the park, including one hidden on the roof of a garage! We'll end the day by walking south along the Hudson to 72nd St., then over to the 1,2,3 train at Broadway.  


PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED.

DISTANCE: About 4 miles.

PACE: MODERATE (2.5 MPH), NOT SLOW.  PLEASE, IF YOU WANT TO WALK SLOWLY, THIS IS NOT THE RIGHT EVENT FOR YOU. I DON'T ENJOY WALKING SLOWLY, AND I WILL NOT WAIT FOR STRAGGLERS.

FINISH AT: Around 5 PM. But you can leave earlier, of course.

LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll eat in the park at roughly 2:30.

COST: $2, in part to cover Meetup’s recently increased organizer fee.

TRANSPORTATION: #1 train to 110th St. For more details, consult hopstop.com, mta.tripplanner.org, or both, since each is occasionally inaccurate. Also check web.mta.info/weekender.html for weekend service changes on your subway lines.

WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient, no matter how many are waiting. The wait list may shrink rapidly, especially at the last minute,  because of cancellations. And you can come if you're in the top 20 on the list (shown below the main list on the right side of this page on a computer--not an app or mobile device) at any time before the walk starts. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up.

results.name: Central Park plus BIG animals at the cathedral!

results.description:
New York City has so much to offer. Even for vegan/vegetarian cuisine, there's a whole world to explore, and I feel lucky to have found such a great group with whom I can share it. But as a resident of the bustling metropolis of New York City, with its asphalt, concrete, steel and glass, I often yearn for a deeper connection with nature. It's sometimes all too easy, in the midst of towering skyscrapers, to forget about the environment we wish to preserve, and the birds and other animals we wish to let live. But let's not forget about this little oasis we have in the heart of the city -- Central Park.

Please join us then, on a beautiful early fall day, for our meetup's fourth annual picnic in Central Park.

Time: 12pm to 3pm

What to bring: Please bring enough food for yourself. You may want to bring a blanket or beach towel to sit on. Be sure to bring beverages to drink, including water. Everything else is up to you. If you do wish to share food, just keep in mind that not everyone has exactly the same level of dietary restrictions. Likewise, if you wish to participate in physical activities (frisbee, yoga, etc.), just remember that everyone has different limits. [David says: I am bringing some Frisbees. Let's play Frisbee! And feel free to bring your own Frisbee, ball or game/toy.]

</a>

<a href="http://www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/north-end/great-hill.html">

</a>

<a href="http://www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/north-end/great-hill.html">

</a>

<a href="http://www.centralparknyc.org/visit/things-to-see/north-end/great-hill.html">

Location: Central Park's Great Hill, an open hilltop meadow with picnic tables, on the west side from 103rd to 107th St. We will have a Meetup sign. From the intersection of W 106th Street and Central Park West, walk up the stairs leading into the park, and you will end at the Great Hill. We will be found on top of the Great Hill. There are public bathrooms near the north west corner of the hill.

Directions to picnic site: Enter Central Park at 106th Street and Central Park West for easy access to the Great Hill. Just walk up the stairs you will see at 106th Street and Central Park West. USE THE STAIRCASE ON THE RIGHT. We will be at the hill at the top of the stairs.

For those of you who have never attended one of our Meetup events: this is an incredibly friendly & welcoming group. If this is your first-time event, we welcome you to join us and make some wonderful vegetarian & vegan friends. (And all you regular members already know what great members we have, so please come join us on this beautiful day.)

By subway: B,C to 103rd and Central Park West or the 1 to 103rd and Broadway. By bus: M10 on Central Park West; M7 or M11 going north on Amsterdam Avenue or south on Columbus Avenue; M104 on Broadway. From the East Side, the M96 to 96th and Central Park West.

We are looking forward to seeing you, hanging out, and enjoying veg*n food on this beautiful early fall day. Let's have a picnic!

- Eddie

[David says: While I am helping Eddie host on the day of the picnic, Eddie is the one who got the permit from the Parks Dept. and put this whole event together. Thank you very much, Eddie!!]

Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked].

$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$

IF YOU DECIDE TO ATTEND YOU WILL NEED TO PRE-PAY USING THIS LINK: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/american-museum-of-natural-history-museum-scavenger-hunt-tickets-18843836422

$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$

Discover all that the American Museum of Natural History has to offer while socializing and exploring its many halls with other fun people from NYSN and other social networking groups.  You will be teamed up with others ( unless you already have a team ) and set out on an afternoon adventure that you won’t forget!  If you have done this hunt before no worries we have all new clues for you! The Hunt will take you through the many exhibits at the museum as you look for clues and answers to the questions that we will challenge you with.  The Hunt will take you about 90 Minutes and the first team to finish with the most the clues will be our winners!  All the teams will gather at a local tavern when you finish where we will tally up the results, eat, drink and socialize!

The Fee includes admission to the museum and the hunt!

Following lunch you are invited to go back to the museum to enjoy all the exhibits at a more leisurely pace or hang out at our party at The Columbus Avenue Street Fair

Can I come alone? Yes, we will randomly set you up on teams of 5.

How does it work? The group will meet at The Firehouse Tavern.  We will put you on a team and hand you a sheet with about 30 different clues that you will need to find the answers to in the museum.

What should I wear?  It's a weekend, be casual and comfortable.  You will be doing a lot of walking in the museum so wear comfortable shoes.

What to bring: camera or camera phone

What is included?

-Admission to the museum

-Scavenger hunt fee

If you do not see a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?  Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and www.newyorksocialnetwork.com.  There will be many people attending from other groups, YOU WILL NOT BE ALONE!  If you want to know exact numbers or have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>
results.name: Tennis Social

results.description:
Updated September 5th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

results.description:
Dowsing can enhance your Yoga practice and your awareness of your chakras. Dowsing helps you tune in to your subtle energy centers and specific vibrations and wavelengths to help improve your body’s health and discipline your mind—the goals of Yoga. By the end of this workshop, you will understand what dowsing is, have a basic knowledge of what frequency/vibration is, begin to determine what dowsing method works the best for you, and start to share ideas on how you can use dowsing in your everyday life. Dowsing demonstrations will be performed; you will practice with your own dowsing instrument or your own body. You may wish to bring a pendulum or a dowsing instrument that you use, though an instrument is not necessary.

To complete RSVP follow the link below


http://iyiny.org/workshops-and-events/calendar/subtle-energy-and-6436/
results.name: Subtle Energy and the Human Body An Introduction to Dowsing

group.name: Reclaim Your Health/Subtle Energy workshops meetup

results.description:
A Women’s Circle & Playshop. 

Come immerse yourself in this juicy expressive-arts process within a circle of warm & like-minded women!

Take this afternoon to connect with your creative self in a warm, supportive environment of other like-minded women. Come immerse yourself in this juicy expressive arts process!

No need for any artistic ability. Just come with an open mind and an open heart!

We will be using the vehicle of SoulCollage® which allows you move past your linear rational mind and step through the doorway into your own deep guidance….. your intuition. This magical process can be used to offer insight into both the big and small decisions in life, clarify solutions to nagging problems, and give you an expressive outlet that is nourishing and joyful.

By using images from magazines, books, and art, you make cards - each collaged card representing one aspect of your personality or Soul. Over time you construct your own deck of unique, soul-tending cards.

You will learn how to interpret the cards and use them intuitively to answer life's questions or explore your inner landscape and reconnect with your deepest wisdom!

All materials are provided! 

No previous training necessary!

During the SoulCollage® Playshop you will receive… 

• Instruction on the SoulCollage® process

• Plenty of card-making time

• Guided card interpretation

• Group sharing

• All card-making materials (you only need to bring a journal if you wish)

• A plethora of sumptuous images for your card-making pleasure

• A lovely folder to take home: lots of handouts and resources, a blank SoulCollage® board and a card-making frame to get you started creating at home 

• PLUS...Cynthia’s personal attention and guidance throughout!

$65 - pre-registration required  -  Invest in your BRILLIANCE!


Cynthia Shaw is is a licensed mental health counselor in private practice for 25 years and has been a SoulCollage® facilitator since 2005. She is also an artist who believes that creativity is as important as breathing. Art and creativity have been Cynthia’s guides to greater self-understanding and wild, luscious fulfillment….. and she LOVES to share that joy with YOU!
results.name: Tapping into your Most Brilliant, Creative Self -         a SoulCollage®Journey

results.description:
The Church of the Resurrection's blessing of the animals will begin Sunday at 12:40 p.m. after Mass ends at the church at 119 E. 74th St., according to Father Sean Wallace, who is coordinating the blessing. Two priests in full vestments will bless each animal.

Dogs, cats, birds, rabbits and other pets and their owners are all welcome to the blessing, which will take place outside the church.

Father Wallace said he is inviting carriage drivers and mounted police officers to bring their horses, as well.

"This is our gift to the community, and no contribution is required. We just want people to come and have their animals blessed," he said.

The event is the biggest of its kind on the East Side, he added.

"The blessing is pretty well known on this street," he said. "We've been doing this for 10 years now. People bring their sick dogs, but it's also a nice opportunity for people to come and meet others with pets."
results.name: Blessing of the Animals (Manhattan)

group.name: Plans for Pups (PfP) -- We have plans for pups!

results.description:
This meetup is kicking Ocktoberfest in NYC with a bang. For all beer lovers, beer aficionados and just overall thirst for all things alcohol.
Queens—a brewery hotbed for German immigrants before Prohibition—rejuvenates its sudsy past with this 5,000-square-foot microbrewery and tasting room. It produces souped-up versions of classic styles, such as a Double Umlaut Lagrrr!, a German bock aged in old Jamaican rum barrels. Other offerings include a boozy Imperial Full Stack IPA and 19-33 Lagrrr!, an aggressively hopped pilsner.
Sip a stein in the 25-seat tasting room, handsomely appointed with mahogany walls, red oak communal tables and hanging metallic lamp.
Here is the website for the brewery. They offer a variety of beers on tap and also have a full pub style menu.

http://www.singlecutbeer.com/beers/category/year-round/
results.name: Ocktoberfest For beer Lovers!!

Hi Guardians!

We are going Back to Nature!

We have been tour!

Now we are returning to The Museum of Natural History. Every Month. Same Time. Same place. Until further notice. We meet parallel to the Brights and TRU.

Our monthly Museum Walk and Talk is still the first Sunday of every month! Same time at 1pm under the lobby dinos (at or near...they did some renovations...). At 1:30 we move to the downstairs cafe to nosh and chat. Then we start exploring at 2:30. I usually have a blue New York Atheists hat on and a small brights button.

Generally, we try to keep it cheap and educational. The Museum of Natural History's admission is by donation.


Bright Cheers Evolving (BCE),
Charlie [masked], mobile)

"In general people are not born stupid. True stupidity
is achieved only through great effort, such as the Creation Museum in Petersburg, KY"

Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY  (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:
http://www.nybg.org/frida/index.php

Frida Kahlo одна из наиболее значительных и узнаваемых Мексиканских художниц начала 20 века.

Жена художника коммуниста Diego Rivera. Любовница Льва Троцкого. В круг общения Frida Kahlo входили художники Marcel Duchamp(кубизм, концептуальное исскуство) и Pablo Picasso(Кубизм, constructed sculpture,collage)

Фигура яркая и неоднозначная. За свою короткую жизнь(47 лет) Frida Kahlo создала картины которые являются не только культурным достоянием Мексики но и мирового художественного фонда

Frida Kahlo de Rivera (July 6, 1907 – July 13, 1954; Magdalena Carmen Frieda Kahlo y Calderón) was a Mexican painter, born in Coyoacán. Perhaps best known for her self-portraits, Kahlo's work is remembered for its "pain and passion", and its intense, vibrant colors. Her work has been celebrated in Mexico as emblematic of national and indigenous tradition, and by feminists for its uncompromising depiction of the female experience and form.

 At the age of 18, she was seriously injured in a bus accident.

At 22 she married the famous Mexican muralist Diego Rivera, 20 years her senior. Their stormy, passionate relationship survived infidelities, the pressures of careers, divorce, remarriage.

During her lifetime, Frida created some 200 paintings, drawings and sketches related to her experiences in life, physical and emotional pain and her turbulent relationship with Diego. She produced 143 paintings, 55 of which are self-portraits.

Both Frida and Diego were very active in the Communist Party in Mexico. In early July 1954, Frida made her last public appearance, when she participated in a Communist street demonstration. Soon after, on July 13th, 1954, at the age of 47, Frida passed away.

Tikets: $25

http://www.nybg.org/visit/tickets.php

Directions:

http://www.nybg.org/visit/directions.php

2900 Southern Blvd., Bronx, NY 10458

Join us for a Sunday of Making with littleBits, circuits, Arduino and more! Bring in your own project or dig in with littleBits kits available to use for free!

littleBits makes a growing library of electronic modules that snap together with magnets for prototyping, learning, and fun. 

Each module has a specific function (motors, lights, sound, sensors, buttons, thresholds, pulse, wireless control, etc.), and all modules snap to make larger circuits. Building circuits is simple and intuitive, allowing anyone to create powerful, sophisticated electronics in a matter of seconds. 

MacInspires will present an Intro Workshop to littlebits, covering the different modules by creating fun projects!

results.description:
Please note that today we'll only be meeting from 1pm-3pm to create characters.

Due in part to the new Occult Adventure Book I have decided on running a, non-Golarion, Anime style campaign.

1) Player characters start off at 5th level (same stat buying system as I have already established).

2) Races: Core Rulebook Races ONLY!

3) Hit Points: Level 1 max and half+1 thereafter

4) Party must have some sort of balanced synergy (ie: DPS, Tank, Healer, Nuke..etc.

5) #4 being said, please have a few varying character concepts (different party roles) and on this, Sunday 9/6, we'll spend the first  hour or two together; hashing out the character concepts and building a "balanced" party. In addition to actually playing.

6) Remember, you're playing a "living and breathing character" and not just a bunch of stats. 

7) Limited Creation Feats (only Scroll and Brewing Potions)

Very Basic Backstory:

- Like in most fantasy Anime the plethora of "real world" human races are all represented on the continent.

- Your character is a member of a "Family" (no actual relationships needed) of "Monster" hunters (in this case Monster can mean Undead, Demon, Magic Beast...etc).

- The country you're in is undergoing severe social changes and there are citizens whom have been mysteriously missing and the local gov't doesn't seem to be doing much about it. 

- Arcane magic is viewed superstitiously and magic items are a bit rarer than typical western fantasy campaigns.

Permissible Pathfinder Source Material:
1) Core Rulebook
2) Advance Class Guide
3) Advanced Race Guide (to be a non-core race first you need to roll a natural 20 prior to character creation)
4) Advanced Player's Guide
5) Occult Adventures
6) Pathfinder Unchained
7) Ultimate Combat
8) Ultimate Magic
9) The Inner Sea World Guide
10) Ultimate Campaign

The following may or may not have material for character creation but I'm listing all Pathfinder soft-bounds I own:

1) Advanced Class Origins
2) Alchemy Manual
3) Animal Archive
4) Blood of Angels (see # 3 Advanced Race Guide)
5) Blood of the Night (ditto)
6) Princes of Darkness
7) Lords of Chaos
8) Horsemen of the Apocalypse
9) Champions of Purity
10) Chronicle of the Righteous
11) Cities of Golarion
12) Classic Treasure Revisted
13) Demon Hunter's Handbook
14) Dungeon's of Golarion
15) Faiths & Philosphies
16) Halflings of Golarion
17) Humans of Golarion
18) Inner Sea Combat
19) Inner Sea Primer
20) Knights of the Inner Sea
21) Melee Tactics Toolbook
22) Occult Mysteries
23) Paths of Prestige
24) Ranged Tactics Toolbox
25) Technology Guide
26) Tombs of Golarion
27) Towns of the Inner Sea
28) Undead Revisted
29) Undead Slayer's Handbook
30) Undead Unleashed
31) Dragon Empire Gazeteer
32) Dragon Empires Primer

COMMON COURTESY:

a) Please be on time...it's not fair to those that show up on time and having them wait. Consistent tardiness shall result in removal. 

b) During the actual adventure please do not use it as Pathfinder library time and read through source material that doesn't directly pertain to the adventure at hand.

c) If you do in fact RSVP, please be 100% certain that you are available to play this day and time.  Space is limited and so is the RSVP list.  Don't simply take and hold a place if you're truly not certain. Repeat offenders shall be removed and banished to the Bog of Eternal Stench!!!

October 4, 2015

Introduction to Santeria

It's History Origins Hierarchy in the Santeria Pantheon Archetypes Being Crowned Becoming a Santero Taught by one of our High Priestess who has experienced some of this first hand

$25 in person/$27 via paypal - PLEASE bring your receipt to class.

WFT Academy of Pagan Studies (WFTAPS) offers the most comprehensive, well-planned and affordable training available anywhere. We have a very interactive community based program. We provide many sources of learning that go into each and every class, which surpasses others when learning about Wicca / WitchCraft in New York City. We offer First through Third Degree training. Additionally we have many other Witch Crafting Classes & Workshops including: Herbal Intensive Series, Making A BOS, Tarot Classes, Besom Making, Candle SpellCrafting and much more.

What is wonderfully unique about WFT Academy of Pagan Studies is that it allows you to set the pace of your learning experience and provides you with an affordable way to grow within a structured Wiccan learning environment. You will be challenged and we do invite those who welcome this challenge to our Academy. We take your education very seriously, and in turn you should be serious about your education and training in the Path of Wicca / WitchCraft. Before considering enrollment and training at WFT Academy of Pagan Studies keep in mind that it is a life-path commitment.

Within our Academy there is an enormous amount of Community Interaction through the use of meetups, myspace, groups and now NEW! launching in 2013 online classes which will have our newly formed blog and forum etc., further enabling you to increase your knowledge and learning as well as providing you the ability to network with other like-minded individuals in a safe and supportive environment.  Students can join this blog as long as they have registered at WFTAPS for classes

The Academy is truly a Spiritual Home and we welcome you to make it your own!

We have Degree-specific Study to discuss challenging lessons, facilitate rituals celebrating the Sabbats and Esbats as well as for healing and self-empowerment, all in a friendly and open atmosphere. We also hold Wiccan Degree dedications marking the stages of your training as you move through the Academy. We have found that many of our Students find it wonderful to be in a group learning environment that they can consider a Community Home.

We are all very proud of our Academy and what we have accomplished thus far. But ever mindful that it is each and every one of the Students that make it what it is. If you are reading this, we are confident that you would make a wonderful addition to our Academy and do hope that after reading this, you will decide to join us as at the Academy as a Student and member of The Wiccan Family Temple.

We welcome you to begin your studies by going to our ADMISSION AND PRICES (where you will find applications) page and submit your enrollment to the Academy today. We look forward to having you join us as a new Student of the WFT Academy of Pagan Studies.

WE ARE ALWAYS IMPROVING UPON WHAT WE OFFER STRIVING AND PROMISING TO ALWAYS KEEP RAISING THE BAR ON WHAT WE OFFER.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON CLASSES, EVENTS ETC. PLEASE VISIT US AT:
www.wftacademyofpaganstudies.webs.com
www.wiccanfamilytemple.org
www.thenycpagancouncil.webs.com
www.romanctichandfastings.webs.com
www.charmedbystarr.com for all your ritual and pagan items.

Hi Brights, locals and visitors, out of state and international!

Also, to those who are curious about The Brights (the-brights.net) or who we are allied with. You are welcome to explore natural reality with us too!)


As Always: The Museum of Natural History. Every Month. Same Time. Same place. Until further notice.

(Please Note: To further our efforts at remembrance of those like-minded friends who have past away, we are exploring ideas to entrench and revisit their inspirations by creating a fund to set up benches, plaques, fountains and other things in our city. This will be an ongoing discussion until implemented.)


Our monthly Museum Walk and Talk is perpetually on the first Sunday of every month! Same time at 1pm under the lobby dinosaurs (at or near, in the round). At 1:30 we move to the downstairs cafe to nosh and chat. Then we start exploring at 2:30. I usually have a blue New York Atheists hat on and a small brights buttons.

Generally, we try to keep it cheap and educational. The Museum of Natural History's admission is by donation. several of us are members and therefore we take people in as guests as we can. The museum itself is by donation so it is very accessible to everyone. Never avoid coming if you feel you cannot afford it. Just let me know in confidence.


Other events are planned ad-hoc and the city and tri-state  is our oyster...

RSVPs are appreciated but not required unless specifically stated.

Bright Cheers Evolving (BCE),
Charlie [masked], mobile)
Acting Director of The New York Brights

 

"In general people are not born stupid. True stupidity
is achieved only through great effort, such as the Creation Museum in Petersburg, KY"

-Giddian, a Brights Leader, is http://itanjo.com/... and Atheist Axioms at Cafe Press
results.why: Our Bright Walk and Talks are explorations of science, culture and reality with informal chat between like-minded, respectful people.

results.description:
This experiential workshop helps us develop tools for nurturing ourselves so that we can nurture all of nature.  We become more resilient so that we may liver deeper, and more joyful and ethical lives.  

Registration is not  open yet, but to do save the date!

General information follows:

Nurturing Nature:  Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth’s

A workshop that helps us live compassionately, joyfully, and healthy in a multispecies world

As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us.  We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves.  One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. 

This Nurture Nature Workshop...

-Seeks to remedy that situation by inviting participants to a lifelong discovery of nature accompanied by practice and discipline that that will provide resources and resilience for living compassionately.  By accepting our own inner animal, our compassion spreads outrageously beyond kin and kind to all of life. 

-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.

- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth.  These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices. 

- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister.  She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species.  Currently she serves life as the Director of One Earth Conservation and Ministry, facilitating learning and practice communities such as this workshop and also collaborating on multiple teams throughout Latin America that seek to heal our biotic communities through incorporating the human dimension in parrot conservation.

-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.

- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth.  These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices. 

- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister.  She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species.  Currently she serves life as the Director of One Earth Conservation and Ministry, facilitating learning and practice communities such as this workshop and also collaborating on multiple teams throughout Latin America that seek to heal our biotic communities through incorporating the human dimension in parrot conservation.
results.name: Nurture Nature Workshop

results.description:
This is a workshop that helps us live the Conservationist's Way - Nurturing ourselves so that we can nurture not just human nature, but all of nature. Registration is not open yet, but please save the date.

General information follows:

I will post registration information here.


Nurturing Nature: Yours, Ours, Theirs, the Earth’s

A workshop that helps us live compassionately, joyfully, and healthy in a multispecies world

As never before, humans feel disconnected from nature and the beings that co-inhabit the earth with us. We strongly desire to care for other species and ecosystems, and are unsure how we can maximize flourishing for individuals of all species, as well as for ourselves. One key to the many living well is to remember that we exist in an interdependent web where all beings are connected to each other in inherent worth, dignity and beauty. This Nurture Nature Workshop...

-Seeks to remedy that situation by inviting participants to a lifelong discovery of nature accompanied by practice and discipline that that will provide resources and resilience for living compassionately. By accepting our own inner animal, our compassion spreads outrageously beyond kin and kind to all of life.
-Builds community and fosters relationships through slowing down, sharing experiences, and co-designing activities that nourish us and all of nature.
- Offers learning, practice, and discussion involving concrete foundations that clear the way for us to nurture ourselves, others, and the earth. These foundations draw on science, psychology, communication theory and practices, and various spiritual and religious approaches such as Albert Schweitzer’s Reverence for Life ethic and a variety of mindfulness practices.
- Engages and stimulates us through activities, such as music videos, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussion and exercises, games, meditation, role-plays, and nature experiences.

The facilitator, Rev. Dr. LoraKim Joyner, offers to you her skills gained from a lifetime of working with animals as a wildlife veterinarian, and from her experience and training as a Certified Trainer in Nonviolent Communication and a Unitarian Universalist minister. She has devoted her life to addressing the health of humans and nonhumans together, knowing that the health of our biotic communities depends on holding as precious the needs and well-being of all individuals of all species. Los laberintos del amor y la mentira, y el talento desigual como desafío de una pareja son los grandes temas de esta novela de Carla Guelfenbein, una autora que ha deslumbrado a Coetzee y a miles de lectores en el mundo.

A Vera Sigall y Horacio Infante los une un amor de juventud y su pasión por la literatura. También un lazo misterioso que dos jóvenes, Emilia y Daniel, intentan desentrañar. Sin embargo, este no es el único enigma en sus vidas. Una mañana, Vera Sigall cae por las escaleras de su casa y queda en coma. Al principio, la noción de que su caída no fue un accidente aparece como una sospecha para Daniel. Pero con los días y las semanas, la duda irá creciendo hasta volverse una certeza.

Emilia y Daniel se encontrarán en la búsqueda de la verdad acerca del accidente de la mítica escritora pero, sobre todo, en la necesidad de entender sus propios destinos.

results.description:
Full title: "Everything and More: A Compact History of Infinity," by David Foster Wallace

Equal parts enlightening and humorous, Wallace takes readers on a riveting journey through the temporal history of infinity in terms of human discovery, as well as its timeless quality in mathematics and the world around us.

AMAZON REVIEW:
One of the outstanding voices of his generation, David Foster Wallace has won a large and devoted following for the intellectual ambition and bravura style of his fiction and essays. Now he brings his considerable talents to the history of one of math's most enduring puzzles: the seemingly paradoxical nature of infinity.

Is infinity a valid mathematical property or a meaningless abstraction? The nineteenth-century mathematical genius Georg Cantor's answer to this question not only surprised him but also shook the very foundations upon which math had been built. Cantor's counterintuitive discovery of a progression of larger and larger infinities created controversy in his time and may have hastened his mental breakdown, but it also helped lead to the development of set theory, analytic philosophy, and even computer technology.

Smart, challenging, and thoroughly rewarding, Wallace's tour de force brings immediate and high-profile recognition to the bizarre and fascinating world of higher mathematics.
results.name: BOOK CLUB: "Everything & More: A History of Infinity," by David Foster Wallace

GUEST SPEAKER: Melanie Brewster

Melanie Brewster, Assistant Professor of Psychology and Education at Columbia University, earned her Ph.D from the University of Florida. Her research focuses on marginalized groups and examines how experiences of discrimination and stigma may shape the mental health of minority group members (e.g., LGBTQ individuals, atheists, people of color). Her book, Atheists in America, was released in 2014, and explores how diverse nonbelievers navigate "coming out" in the United States. She tweets about atheism, queer issues, and academia @melysebrewster

The Bliss Jockeys are a dynamic rock/pop/vocals band with questing lyrics in the grand tradition of Cat Stevens and Bruce Springsteen. Part rock, part gospel & part jam band,  the Bliss Jockeys are thrilled to bring their energizing music to Sunday Assembly again!

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photograph. Thank you again.

Most of the route and artists will be different from the Jersey City Art Walk that I led last year.

Description: Jersey City Artists and Studios Tour (JCAST) has hundreds of participating artists. These artists are opening their doors to the public and sharing their work. The artists don't charge admission to their art studios. We'll stop in some of these art studios and get a rare, intimate view of the artists' working environment. We can also talk to the artists about what they do. This art walk features painting, photography, ceramics, mixed-media, sculpture, and printmaking.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (after lunch) at 2:00 PM.

Meeting Place: The meeting place is outside of the entrance to Duane Reade Pharmacy at 110 Newark Avenue in Jersey City, NJ. The Duane Reade Pharmacy is right next to the Grove Street PATH station. Before the walk, restrooms are available in Dunkin Donuts, MacDonalds and Starbucks, which are all near the Duane Reade Pharmacy. There will also be places to stop for a restroom during the walk.

Below is outside of Duane Reade at 110 Avenue Street near the Grove Street PATH station.

Transportation (from Manhattan): Take the PATH subway train (from Midtown or Greenwich Village) to Grove Street in Jersey City, New Jersey. From Midtown or Greenwich Village, you could take the PATH train from the following PATH stations: 33rd Street/6th Avenue, 23rd Street/6th Avenue, 14th Street/6th Street, 9th Street/6th Avenue, or Christopher Street (between Hudson Street and Greenwich Street.) Once in New Jersey, the PATH subway train will stop in Hoboken, Newport (Jersey City), and then Grove Street (Jersey City). Depending on where you get in the PATH subway system, the train ride is about 14 to 22 minutes.

More Transportation (from Manhattan): You can take a NYC subway train (2, 3, 4, 5, A, C, or R) to the Fulton Center in lower Manhattan. Then walk a short distance and take the PATH subway train from the World Trade Center to Grove Street in Jersey City. Once in New Jersey, the PATH subway train will stop in Exchange Place (Jersey City) and then Grove Street (Jersey City).

The PATH subway fare is $2.75 each way. You can use a New York City MetroCard to pay the fare (as long as it isn't a New York City unlimited MetroCard or a New York City Senior MetroCard.) Therefore, PATH takes only the New York City paid-per-ride MetroCard.

Transportation (from New Jersey): One option is to take a New Jersey transit railroad train to the Newark Penn Station and then switch to a PATH subway train that is going to Grove Street. Both the New Jersey transit railroad trains and the PATH subway are located at Newark Penn Station. Another option is to take a New Jersey transit railroad train to the Hoboken Terminal and then switch to a PATH subway train that is going to Grove Street.

Transportation (Driving): If you want to take your car to the Jersey City art walk, please call the telephone # in the link below to find out about the parking regulations on the weekend in Jersey City.

http://jcparking.org/

Finishing Time/Place: This art walk will finish at about 5:15 PM back at the PATH subway station at Grove Street.

This walk is about 2 1/2 miles.

Because this art walk is held only once per year (and doesn't have a rain date), I will be leading this walk in nearly all-weather conditions. Therefore, if I don't post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning, I plan to be at the meeting place.  If it is raining, I will bring an umbrella. We will be spending half of the time inside these artist studios anyway. If I do cancel this walk, I will post a cancellation notice in the Discussion Board.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

Below is abstract artwork (done in wood, carved, layered and painted) by Abby Levine.

Below is an acrylic painting by Robert Piersanti, whose art studio is in Jersey City.

We will be reading "The Cosmic Shekinah: A History of the Goddess of the Old Testament and Qabalah - Her Origins in Ancient Pagan Culture and modern manifestations." By Sorita d’Este & David Rankine.

The Shekinah is the manifestation of the Wisdom Goddess of the Kabbalah, the Hebrew Bible and Merkavah Mysticism. She encompasses the primordial light of creation, the wisdom of the serpent and the inspiration of the dove. She is the beauty of the lily and the embodiment of the Tree of Life. She is also the World soul, heavenly glory, mother of angels, inspiration for prophecy, and source of souls, as well as being the Shabbat Bride and the wife of God.

Please buy the book if you can. $24.99. If you are broke, then don't worry - I will summarize the book at our meeting. But it's a great book.

http://sorita.co.uk/books/the-cosmic-shekinah/

results.description:
Title: Stealer of the Watch: 

Word Count: 25,720 

Genre: Science Fiction


This is a one-time-only meeting to critique the entire novella. Readers should be prepared to read the entire novella prior to the meeting and be prepared to discuss it based on some questions provided at the end of the manuscript for consideration. Also, any written comments you would like to make as you read would be greatly appreciated!When you RSVP, Alex will send you the entire manuscript.


Teaser: 

    Post-apocalyptic Earth finds a lonely ex-dancer, Rothbart, doing pirouettes on his roof. An enormous spaceship appears from nowhere, frightening him, but after several passes overhead it ejects a small ark. Rothbart finds the ark and discovers he can manipulate it to bring forth creatures, including a pair of humanoid creatures, Adam and Sara. 

   He chases away Adam and begins to copulate with Sara, but when Rothbart discovers she’s pregnant, Sara runs away for fear of what he might do.In the adventure that follows Sara rejoins with Adam and they escape to the dead city, chased by the deranged Rothbart. Along the way they meet a recently reawakened carebot, BG-29, who serves as midwife at the birth of Sara’s children, and begins to teach them about the world they find themselves in. Rothbart finally catches up to the small group, demanding the return of his stolen watch, and wanting to kill his half-human, half-alien children.


  Alex has prepared some questions as a guide, but would also appreciate any notes in the text itself.  Go here to download the story:  https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5WymOhBhMiNY2Y0dGdNTWxHZ1d5bW5KR0VUbkNjRTExbTVz/view?usp=sharing

Thank you for reading!

results.description:
Come and experience Namaste's NEW Spiritual Book Club!

Our first meeting will be October 4th at 3PM and ending at 5PM at Namaste Healing Center and we will be discussing the POWER OF NOW by Eckhart Tolle.

So even if it's your first time reading this great classic or your tenth, come in next Sunday to be inspired and share your insights with like minded Souls.

The new Spiritual Book club will be lead by Jane Dowd Oosterom.  

Jane has just returned to New York from the Netherlands where she had the great experience to lead the Spiritual Book Club at the American Book Center in Amsterdam.  

Jane's passion is teaching and facilitating meditation groups and has a vast spectrum of experiences from a career on Wall Street, a masters in Holistic Ministry and the gift of being a wife and mother.  

Following her passion, she is very excited for the opportunity to create a space where you can share your insights and help shed light on the path leading to your authentic Self.

results.description:
Join us every Sunday from 3pm - 5pm for guided meditation instruction and sitting practice !

Developed for beginners as well as experienced meditators, this afternoon session will include guided instruction, as well as discussion and opportunity for questions and comments.

This is a drop-in event, and pre-registration is not necessary. We're offering it on a donation basis, and request each participant to contribute between $5 - $10 to support this and other initiatives led by The Interdependence Project. For more info, and to learn about other upcoming events at The Interdependence Project, please visit our website, www.theidproject.org .
results.name: Learn to Meditate

results.description:
Deadline for submission of stories to be critiqued is Monday of the week preceeding the Meetup. On Tuesday, an email will be sent, listing the stories to be critiqued and in what order. Print out and mark up your copies in advance or read and mark up electronic comments.

Stories can be any length up to approx. 7,000 words. Flash fiction welcome.

You can submit your story to me (Marcy) directly, or submit to Dropbox per the Procedures (see below). My email is [masked].

Please make sure your manuscript is properly formatted. Read through our Short Story Group Procedures for guidelines and an example, as well as advice for a constructive critique. Having manuscripts already formatted makes the critiquing process easier.

Most of the meeting will be spent critiquing work of group members. There is a structure to make sure critiques are as helpful as possible for everyone involved, so writers leave with a clear idea of what to do next with their stories.

We also spend time talking about writing, sharing news and information, and getting to know one another. It's always easier to take constructive criticism from someone you know!

Flash pieces: If there is time (and there usually is), we can critique one or two last minute flash pieces that weren't submitted. Best method is to print out a copy for each participant. We will read the story there and give on-the-spot critiques.
results.name: Marcy's Short Story Meetup

More details:http://www.theidproject.org/events/2015/05/03/sundays-weekly-introduction-meditation

results.description:
We'll walk across the Wiliamsburg, Manhattan, and Brooklyn bridges, and end with dinner in Chinatown.

The hike will end at the Brooklyn Bridge / Chambers St stop on the 4/5/6/J/Z subways, then those interested will continue on about a dozen blocks to dinner in Chinatown.

We should be arriving at the restaurant around 6pm.  The restaurant is Sichuan, and they agree to do separate checks for us.  Sunset will be at 6:30pm.

Originally I was going to do the bridges in the other order and eat in Williamsburg, but it turns out Williamsburg is too fashionable a neighborhood and the restaurants I found there that were big enough to handle the group size and willing to do separate checks were an unbelievable rip off - $15 for a burger and fries!!!  So we'll be eating in Chinatown.

It gets windy on the bridges, and on the Williamsburg and Brooklyn bridges your hat might blow off and land on subway tracks or a road where you can't recover it.


Attendance at this event is free, and all participants attend at their own risk. Everyone will be required to sign a release waiver that basically gives up any right whatsoever to sue, to the fullest extent possible by law. You can read the current draft of this waiver at http://bluejacket7.com/legal/WalkingWaiver.doc
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the sidewalk in front of MacDonald's on the corner, just west of the west end of the Marcy St subway station of the J/M/Z subway line.  I look like my picture.
results.name: 5.5 Mile Three Bridges Hike

results.description:
In light of the torture scandal that culminated today when the American Psychological Association approved a ban on psychologists' involvement in national security interrogations (http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/08/us/politics/psychologists-approve-ban-on-role-in-national-security-interrogations.html?emc=edit_tnt_20150807&nlid=56323910&tntemail0=y), I think it's a great time to ask ourselves the following questions:

-Why torture?
-When torture?
-How torture?
-Who torture?

These are briefly stated, but should make for an interesting and heated discussion. I can begin the conversation by offering some psychological research findings that may fuel the fire.
results.name: Why Torture?

results.description:
Meet on the american football field (near the entrance close to the public restrooms)!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:30. We typically start 20-30 minutes after 3:30. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated 

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
I'm sending out this notice to you all because I think it's important and could positively change your life.

I have access to an audio program related to the

LAW OF ATTRACTION. It was created by Kevin Trudeau. It's a 13 cd audio set that educates you about what the

LAW OF ATTRACTIONvis and how to use it to your benefit and not to your detriment. It is called YOUR WISH IS YOUR COMMAND

Ever since I first heard YWIYC in 2011 and kept re-listening to it over and over and over again I'd seen how powerful my thoughts and feelings were. As I kept up the repetition of listening to the audios and also reading the books that Kevin recommended I've seen tremendously positive changes in my life.  It's a VERY SIMPLE program and that is part of its POWER.

There is no magic pill or 'secret' given in this program except to say that the secret is basically doing the right things, long enough, consistently, with a good attitude. 

People often listen to programs like this or attend events and 'try' to apply them for a few weeks or a couple months and don't see the results they think they want or that they think or best for them.  Sometimes it takes more than a few weeks or couple months to change our programming that's the results of years, if not decades of previous programming. 

I can allow you to have FREE access to this amazingly powerful and simple audio program via DROPBOX or GOOGLE DRIVE. Send me an email with your email address so i can let you access the program.  Each audio is approximately an hour long. I recommended listening up to 2x to each audio..don't listen to the same one over and over....maybe twice then on to the next....you can re-listen to the whole thing again after if you wish. I actually strongly encourage that.  That has you internalize and become the information more and have you actually create and manifest the circumstances you desire in your life faster and easier.

I'm considering then setting up in person meetings in NYC

or possibly conference calls where we discuss the material and help each other understand it even more. I'm also considering group conference calls as well in order for us to 'mastermind' together and support each other in having the life of our dreams. That means different things to different people and there is no good or bad dreams or goals. We're all individuals and desire different things in life.


Also, if you're interested I can let you know about a mastermind conference I'm attending October 16-18 in Disney/Orlando with my Global Success Club.

This audio program and this club are not for everyone and that's ok. However, if you like what you hear in the audio program and about the Club you could radically, positively change your life for the better!

SEE YOU ON THE BEACHES OF THE WORLD!

JONATHAN A. AUGUST
results.name: LAW OF ATTRACTION----LIFE CHANGING AUDIO PROGRAM- 14 CD SET

group.name: BE, DO, HAVE ANYTHING YOU WANT IN YOUR LIFE!

results.description:
Lorne Jaffe, a long-time member/contributor to NYC Dads Group and a sufferer of depression for over 30 years, is producing this one-night only performance to raise awareness and eradicate the stigma surrounding mental illness. 

Tickets are $25, but NYC Dads Group members and significant others can use the code "nycdads" to receive $5 off. You can purchase tickets at: 

</a>

<a href="https://kayeplayhouse.primetix.com/Tickets/?perfid=223">https://kayeplayhouse.primetix.com/Tickets/?perfid=223

Featured performers include:

• Elizabeth Swados, award-winning composer, director and writer - author of the book My Depression: A Picture Book which recently was adapted by HBO into a documentary film

• Comedian Christian Finnegan who has appeared on “Conan,” “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” and “Chappelle’s Show” among others

• Pop culture writer Jenna Marotta (featured on the websites for Esquire, New York, Playboy, The New York Times Magazine,, etc.)

• Kathleen Frazier - author of Sleepwalker: The Mysterious Makings and Recovery of a Somnambulist 

• Musician Danielle Fiorello, Slam poet Kamilah Holtz, and many more!

Please come support Lorne and 14 brave performers in raising awareness about mental illness!

If you cannot make it but still would like to offer help, you can make a donation here: https://secure.squarespace.com/commerce/donate?donatePageId=55bcd91ae4b068359ac3072a

A $10 donation helps with printing #MyBrave t-shirts

A $25 donation helps with printing programs for the show

A $50 donation helps promote the show in local newspapers and tv and radio stations

A $100 donation helps cover the costs of renting the theater

A $250 donation and above helps plan future This Is My Brave shows in other cities

results.description:
If there is one concept which has been under constant attack by psychologists and philosophers over the last few decades, it is the idea of ‘you’—that you exist as a real entity or ‘self’ inside your own mental space. Many modern philosophers and scientists suggest that this sense of being an 'I' is illusory, or just a simple product of brain activity. Somehow the billions of neurons in your brain work together to produce it, and all of the thoughts and feelings which it incorporates. 


In the Buddhist traditions from which many contemporary mindfulness practices derive, mindfulness techniques evolved as tools for deconstructing our usual view of ourselves and the world, for waking up from conventional, socially reinforced fictions about who we are and how to find happiness. This awakening occurs to the degree that we no longer believe in the self. It involves realizing what’s called in Pali—the language in which the Buddha’s teachings were first recorded—anatta, or non-self.


Resources for Discussion:

Ajahn Brahmali gives a practical approach to understanding of non-self, and how to use this understanding in the practice.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QVQpdbAWSS8

Does Your Self Exist? Is there anyone there inside your mind?
https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/out-the-darkness/201311/does-your-self-exist

'You' Don't Exist: Why an Enduring Self Is a Delusion.
http://www.alternet.org/personal-health/you-dont-exist-why-enduring-self-delusion

The blurred reality of humanity. http://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/the-blurred-reality-of-humanity-2247591.html

How does Buddha come to the conclusion that the self does not exist? 
https://www.quora.com/How-does-Buddha-come-to-the-conclusion-that-the-self-does-not-exist

Location: If the weather is pleasant, then we will meet in Bryant Park by the tables around the carousel. In the event of rain or cold weather, we will meet at 120 Park Avenue (near Grand Central), an indoor public plaza with amenities.  http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcp/html/priv/120park.shtml

Timings: We will start at 4pm and continue till we get exhausted.  Its OK to arrive late or leave early.
results.name: Does the Self Exist? Let's explore from psychological & spiritual perspective.
